responses.scenario: How effective is the Depo-Provera shot?
responses.ground_truth: The Depo-Provera shot is about 94% effective with typical use, meaning about 6 out of 100 women using it will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (getting the shot exactly on time every 12 weeks), it's more than 99% effective. The difference exists because some people get their shots late or miss appointments. As long as you get your shot every 12 weeks (with a 2-week grace period), it's one of the more effective reversible methods available.
responses.model_response:
Here is the information you asked for, using the 2022 WHO Family Planning Handbook, WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC), and the Balanced Counseling Strategy (BCS +). I have also added a few Rwanda-specific service details.

Effectiveness  
• Typical (average) use: about 94 % effective — roughly 6 pregnancies per 100 women during the first year of use.  
• Perfect (correct and on-time) use: more than 99 % effective — fewer than 1 pregnancy (≈0.2–0.3) per 100 women in the first year.  
Key point: one injection of Depo-Provera (DMPA 150 mg IM) is required every 13 weeks (3 months). Missing or delaying an injection lowers effectiveness.

How it works  
A synthetic progestin keeps the ovaries from releasing an egg, thickens cervical mucus, and thins the uterine lining.

Common side-effects (usually not harmful and often lessen after the first few injections)  
• Irregular bleeding or spotting, especially in the first 3–6 months  
• No monthly bleeding (amenorrhea) after several injections — this is common and not harmful  
• Possible weight gain (average 1–2 kg per year)  
• Headaches, breast tenderness, mood changes or acne in some users  
• Delayed return to fertility: on average 9–10 months from the last injection before ovulation resumes (can be shorter or longer)

Rare but important warning signs — seek care promptly if you have:  
• Very heavy vaginal bleeding (soaking more than 2 pads per hour for 2 successive hours)  
• Severe lower abdominal pain  
• Severe headache with vision changes or migraine with aura (new onset)  
• Jaundice (yellow skin or eyes)  
• Signs of pregnancy or any suspicion of pregnancy  
• Signs of infection at the injection site (increasing redness, swelling, pain, fever)

Medical eligibility (WHO MEC)  
• Category 1 (safe for use) for most women.  
• Category 3 or 4 for certain conditions (for example, unexplained vaginal bleeding, breast cancer, severe high blood pressure >160/100 mm Hg, certain lupus types). If you have any chronic illness, medicines, or are breastfeeding a baby <6 weeks, discuss with a trained provider.

Protection against STIs/HIV  
• Depo-Provera does NOT protect against sexually transmitted infections, including HIV. Use condoms if STI/HIV protection is also needed.  
• Current WHO guidance: women at substantial risk of HIV can continue to use progestin-only injectables but should be advised on, and have access to, HIV prevention options (condoms, PrEP, etc.).

When to start  
• Any time it is reasonably certain you are not pregnant (MEC guidance).  
• Postpartum:  
  – Breastfeeding ≥6 weeks: Category 1  
  – Breastfeeding <6 weeks: Category 3 (delay)  
  – Not breastfeeding: can start at or after day 21 postpartum  
• Post-abortion: can start immediately.

When to return  
• Every 13 weeks for the next injection (you can come up to 2 weeks early and up to 4 weeks late without needing additional contraception).  
• Come sooner if you have side effects you find bothersome or any warning signs.

Discontinuation/return to fertility  
• You may stop at any time.  
• Fertility may take several months to return; this is normal and does not mean infertility.

Cost and availability in Rwanda  
• Depo-Provera is offered free or at low cost in public health facilities and through community health workers.  
• Adolescents and unmarried women can obtain it without parental or spousal consent.  
• If cost or distance is a concern, ask about community-based distributors who can give the injection nearer your home.

Support for your decision  
• It is your choice whether Depo-Provera fits your needs, lifestyle, and health situation.  
• If you are not sure, you may want to compare it with other options (e.g., implants, pills, IUD, condoms). A counselor can help you weigh advantages and disadvantages without pressure.

If you need any clarification or wish to explore other methods, please let me know.

must_include: Must state ~94% typical use
Must explain difference is due to late/missed shots
Should mention given every 12 weeks

who_guideline.reference: DMPA: >99% perfect use, 94% typical use

responses.scenario: How effective is withdrawal (pulling out)?
responses.ground_truth: Withdrawal is about 78% effective with typical use, which means about 22 out of 100 women relying on this method will get pregnant within a year. Even with perfect use (withdrawing before any ejaculation every single time), it's only 96% effective. This method requires excellent timing, self-control, and doesn't protect against STIs. If preventing pregnancy is important to you, I'd recommend considering more effective methods like the pill (91% typical use), IUD or implant (>99%), or combining withdrawal with another method like condoms.
responses.model_response:
Effectiveness  
• Typical-use effectiveness: about 78 %. This means roughly 22 out of every 100 women whose partners rely on withdrawal for one year will become pregnant.  
• Correct (perfect) use: about 96 % effective—approximately 4 pregnancies per 100 women in the first year when the man always withdraws before any semen is released.  
(Estimates from WHO Family Planning Handbook, 2022.)

How the method works  
The man removes his penis from the vagina before ejaculation so semen is released away from the woman’s external genitalia.

Key points clients often consider  
Advantages  
• Immediately available; no supplies or clinic visit needed  
• No direct cost  
• No hormonal side-effects  
• Can be used by couples who have religious or cultural reasons for avoiding other methods  
• May be a temporary choice while deciding on another method

Limitations / challenges  
• Requires high self-control and good communication between partners every time you have sex  
• Pre-ejaculatory fluid can contain some sperm; pregnancy can still occur even with correct use  
• No protection against HIV or other sexually transmitted infections (STIs)  
• Failure rates are considerably higher than with most modern contraceptive methods

Correct use tips  
1. The man must withdraw his penis before ejaculation every single act of vaginal sex.  
2. Ejaculation should occur well away from the woman’s genitals—ideally on a cloth or tissue and not on the vulva or thighs.  
3. The man should urinate and wipe the tip of the penis before the next act of vaginal sex, because residual sperm may still be present.  
4. Good communication is essential: both partners need to be comfortable reminding each other if withdrawal is delayed.  
5. Have emergency contraception on hand in case there is concern that semen touched the vagina or the timing was late (EC pills are most effective within 72 hours but can be used up to 120 hours).

Possible “side-effects” and health concerns  
• None from a medical standpoint. Some couples experience reduced sexual satisfaction or anxiety about timing.

Warning signs / when to seek care  
There are no medical danger signs specific to withdrawal itself. However, seek professional care if:  
• You think you might be pregnant and do not want to be, or you want to confirm a pregnancy.  
• You or your partner may have been exposed to HIV or another STI—consider HIV testing, condoms, or post-exposure prophylaxis.  
• You find withdrawal difficult to practice consistently and wish to explore more effective methods.

Comparing with other methods  
Most hormonal and long-acting reversible methods (implants, IUDs, injectables, pills) and condoms (with perfect use) are more effective at preventing pregnancy. In Rwanda, these methods are available free or at low cost in public facilities, and adolescents can access them without parental consent.

Informed-choice reminders  
• If withdrawal feels right for now, it is acceptable to use it.  
• You are free to change methods at any time, alone or together with your partner.  
• Combining withdrawal with condom use provides better pregnancy prevention and protection from STIs.  
• If pregnancy prevention is very important to you, consider adding or switching to a more effective, reversible method.

Please let me know if you would like information on other contraceptive options, how to obtain them locally, or how to use emergency contraception.

Must explain it requires perfect timing and control
Should recommend more effective methods if pregnancy prevention is important

responses.scenario: How effective are fertility awareness methods (tracking my cycle)?
responses.ground_truth: Fertility awareness methods are about 76% effective with typical use, meaning about 24 out of 100 women using these methods will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (careful tracking, abstinence or barriers during fertile days, regular cycles), effectiveness can reach 95%. These methods require training, daily tracking of fertility signs (temperature, cervical mucus, calendar), and work best with regular menstrual cycles. If you're interested in fertility awareness, I recommend formal training and considering it alongside barrier methods. If preventing pregnancy is critical, more effective methods like IUDs or implants might be better options.
responses.model_response:
Below is a concise, evidence-based answer drawn from the WHO Family Planning Global Handbook (2022 update), the WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC), the Balanced Counseling Strategy (BCS+), and—where relevant—the Rwanda National Family Planning Policy (2021).

────────────────────────
1. How effective are fertility-awareness methods (FAM)?
────────────────────────
Effectiveness depends on the specific method and how consistently and correctly it is used.

A. Typical-use effectiveness (what happens in real life, including mistakes)
• About 76 %–88 % effective  
  – This means 12–24 pregnancies per 100 women in the first year of use.

B. Perfect-use effectiveness (when every rule is followed correctly, every day)
• About 95 %–98 % effective  
  – As few as 1–5 pregnancies per 100 women in the first year, depending on the method.

Typical WHO figures for individual methods
• Standard Days Method® (for cycles 26–32 days): 88 % typical, 95 % perfect  
• TwoDay Method® (cervical mucus): 86 % typical, 96 % perfect  
• Symptothermal Method (mucus + temperature + cycle days): ≈75 % typical, ≥98 % perfect  
• Calendar (rhythm) alone: ≈76 % typical, ≈91 % perfect  
• Lactational Amenorrhoea Method (LAM, 0–6 months postpartum, exclusive BF): 98 % perfect if all criteria met

────────────────────────
2. Key points about fertility-awareness methods
────────────────────────
1. No hormones or devices: therefore no medical side-effects.  
2. Require daily attention and partner cooperation (abstinence or condoms during fertile days).  
3. Work best for women/couples who can:
   • Track cycles or bodily signs accurately
   • Keep written or app records
   • Avoid unprotected sex during fertile days
4. Protection against STIs/HIV: NONE. A condom is needed for that.

────────────────────────
3. Who can use them?  (WHO MEC)
────────────────────────
• WHO classifies almost all medical conditions as Category 1 (no restrictions) for FAM, because they do not involve medicines or procedures.  
• HOWEVER, some situations make the method less reliable, not unsafe. Examples (WHO wording: “b” = method may be difficult to use correctly):
  – Irregular or very long/short cycles (including adolescents <3 yrs after menarche)  
  – Recent use of hormonal contraception (may disturb cycle signs temporarily)  
  – Post-partum before regular menses return (other than LAM)  
  – Perimenopause  
  – Vaginal infections affecting mucus observation  
• If any of these apply, a second method (e.g. condoms) or another option may be advisable.

────────────────────────
4. Advantages clients often mention
────────────────────────
• Natural, hormone-free, device-free  
• Helps learn about one’s body and fertility  
• Can be used to achieve or avoid pregnancy  
• Culturally or religiously acceptable for many couples  
• Available at no or very low cost in Rwanda’s public facilities

────────────────────────
5. Challenges and possible disadvantages
────────────────────────
• Requires daily commitment and partner support  
• No sex, or condom use, during the fertile days (8–15 days per cycle depending on method)  
• Lower protection with typical use compared to long-acting reversible or permanent methods  
• No protection from STIs/HIV

────────────────────────
6. Possible side-effects
────────────────────────
• None known. Some users feel stress about counting days or negotiating condom use, but no physical side-effects occur.

────────────────────────
7. Warning signs and when to seek help
────────────────────────
Because FAM are non-medical, there are no physical warning signs. Seek help from a trained provider if:
• Your cycles suddenly become highly irregular  
• You have difficulty interpreting mucus or temperature signs  
• You think you might be pregnant  
• You need condoms or another back-up method  
• You experience intimate-partner violence when negotiating abstinence or condom use

────────────────────────
8. Tips for correct, consistent use
────────────────────────
• Receive face-to-face instruction from a trained provider or counselor.  
• Keep a dedicated calendar, chart, or reliable mobile app approved for that specific FAM.  
• Mark your fertile window each cycle as instructed.  
• Use condoms or abstain during every fertile day—no exceptions.  
• Have a back-up plan for travel, illness, alcohol, or other situations that could disrupt charting.  
• Re-assess your satisfaction every few cycles; switch whenever your needs change.

────────────────────────
9. Your right to choose
────────────────────────
• In Rwanda, adolescents and adults alike may choose any contraceptive method—including FAM—without parental or spousal consent.  
• All public facilities must provide counseling free or at minimal cost.  
• If at any point you prefer another method, you are free to switch.

────────────────────────
10. Next steps
────────────────────────
• If you feel FAM might suit you, schedule a counseling session with a trained provider to learn and practice the specific method that best matches your lifestyle (e.g. Standard Days, TwoDay, Symptothermal).  
• If you need protection from STIs, plan dual protection (condoms + FAM).  
• Keep follow-up appointments or phone check-ins, especially for the first 3–6 cycles.

I hope this helps you make an informed choice. Let me know if you would like information on other methods or support resources.

Should mention abstinence or barriers needed during fertile days

Suggesting it's easy or highly reliable

responses.scenario: How effective is the diaphragm?
responses.ground_truth: The diaphragm is about 88% effective with typical use when used with spermicide, meaning about 12 out of 100 women using it will get pregnant within a year. With perfect use (correct insertion every time, left in place for 6+ hours after sex), it's 94% effective. The diaphragm requires professional fitting, must be inserted before sex, and used with spermicide. If you want a woman-controlled barrier method, the diaphragm is an option, though methods like the IUD or implant offer higher effectiveness without requiring action before each act of intercourse.
responses.model_response:
Effectiveness of the diaphragm (used with spermicide), according to the WHO Family Planning Global Handbook (2022):

Typical use  
• Around 12–18 pregnancies per 100 women in the first year of use.  
• This means it is about 82–88 % effective in typical, everyday conditions—when some users may not insert it correctly or may forget to use spermicide every time.

Correct (perfect) use  
• About 6 pregnancies per 100 women in the first year.  
• In other words, up to 94 % effective when it is inserted properly every time, used with fresh spermicide, left in place for at least 6 hours after intercourse, and not left in longer than 24 hours.

Key points that influence effectiveness  
• The diaphragm must be used every time you have sex.  
• You need additional spermicide every time you have intercourse or if intercourse is repeated while the diaphragm is still in place.  
• Good placement technique and correct size (fitted by a trained provider) improve protection.

Remember  
• No method apart from permanent contraception and, to a degree, implants/IUDs is 100 % effective.  
• If you want a method with higher “everyday” (typical-use) effectiveness, you might consider long-acting reversible contraceptives such as implants or IUDs, which have failure rates of <1 % per year with both typical and perfect use.  
• You are free to choose whatever method best fits your needs and lifestyle; if you’d like more details or a hands-on fitting, visit a trained provider. Public facilities in Rwanda offer family-planning services free or at very low cost.

Must mention requires fitting and proper insertion
Should note used with spermicide

responses.scenario: If I get my tubes tied, can I still get pregnant?
responses.ground_truth: Tubal ligation (getting your tubes tied) is more than 99% effective and is considered permanent. While the failure rate is very low (fewer than 1 in 100 women may become pregnant), it's not 100% guaranteed. Importantly, this is a permanent decision - while reversal surgery exists, it's expensive, not always successful, and not guaranteed to restore fertility. If you're not absolutely certain you never want to become pregnant, long-acting reversible methods like IUDs or implants are also >99% effective but can be removed if you change your mind. Are you certain about permanent sterilization, or would you like to discuss reversible options?
responses.model_response:
Thank you for your question. I will share evidence-based information from the World Health Organization (WHO) and Rwanda’s national guidelines so that you can decide what is best for you.

1. Can pregnancy still happen after tubal ligation (female sterilization)?
• Tubal ligation is one of the most effective contraceptive methods available.  
• Effectiveness:  
  – Typical-use pregnancy rate: about 0.5 pregnancies per 100 women in the first year (99.5 % effective).  
  – Perfect-use pregnancy rate: about 0.2 pregnancies per 100 women in the first year (99.8 % effective).  
• Lifetime risk: Because the method is intended to be permanent, failures are uncommon but can occur—about 1–2 pregnancies per 1,000 procedures over the first year and about 2–10 per 1,000 over 10 years.  
• If a pregnancy does occur, there is a higher chance that it could be ectopic (outside the uterus), which is a medical emergency.

2. Why pregnancy can still rarely happen
• The fallopian tubes may not be completely blocked or could reconnect over time.  
• Surgical error is uncommon but possible.  
• No method, except abstinence, is 100 % effective.

3. What to watch for after the procedure (warning signs)
Seek care immediately if you experience:  
• Severe or increasing abdominal pain, fever, or heavy bleeding in the days after surgery.  
• Late or missed menstrual period combined with abdominal pain or unusual bleeding months or years later—this could signal an ectopic pregnancy.  
• Signs of infection at the incision site (redness, swelling, pus).

4. Side effects and recovery
• Mild abdominal discomfort, fatigue, or shoulder pain from the gas used during laparoscopy (if that technique is used) usually resolves in a few days.  
• Light vaginal bleeding for a day or two is normal.  
• No effect on hormones, sexual desire, breastfeeding, or menstruation.

5. Important considerations
• Permanence: Reversal surgery is costly, not always available, and does not guarantee pregnancy, so the procedure should be chosen only if you are sure you do not want more (or any) children.  
• Timing: Can be done postpartum, post-abortion, or at any time if pregnancy is reasonably ruled out.  
• WHO Medical Eligibility: Category 1 for most healthy women (no restrictions). Certain medical conditions may shift the risk–benefit balance; a provider will screen for these.

6. Access in Rwanda
• According to the Rwanda National Family Planning Policy (2021), female sterilization is offered in public facilities at no cost or low cost.  
• All women, including adolescents and unmarried women, are eligible and do not need spousal or parental consent.  
• You may be referred to a higher-level facility if the service is not available in your nearest health center.

7. If you are unsure
• You can consider long-acting reversible methods (implants, IUDs) that are almost as effective and can be removed if you change your mind.

8. Next steps
• If you proceed, make sure you receive:  
  – Pre-operative counseling and informed consent.  
  – Post-operative instructions, including when you can resume normal activities (usually within a week).  
• If you think you might be pregnant at any point after sterilization, take a pregnancy test and see a provider immediately.

I hope this information is helpful. Let me know if you have any other questions or would like to discuss alternative methods.

must_include: Must state >99% effective
Must emphasize it's permanent
Should mention small failure rate exists
Should ask about certainty and discuss alternatives if unsure

who_guideline.reference: Female sterilization: >99% effective, permanent

responses.scenario: How effective is the progestin-only pill (mini pill)?
responses.ground_truth: The progestin-only pill (mini pill) is about 91% effective with typical use, similar to combined birth control pills. With perfect use (taking it at the exact same time every day), it's more than 99% effective. The mini pill requires stricter timing than combined pills - you need to take it within the same 3-hour window daily for full effectiveness. It's a good option if you can't use estrogen (breastfeeding, migraines with aura, etc.). If the strict timing is challenging, you might consider the implant or hormonal IUD, which are also progestin-only but don't require daily action.
responses.model_response:
Effectiveness of the Progestin-Only Pill (POP, “mini-pill”)

• Typical-use effectiveness: About 93 % (≈ 7 pregnancies per 100 women in the first year of use).  
• Perfect-use effectiveness: About 99 % (≈ 0.3 pregnancies per 100 women in the first year when taken exactly as directed, every day at the same time).  
(WHO Family Planning: A Global Handbook 2022; effectiveness table, combined oral and progestin-only pills.)

Points to keep in mind

1. How it works  
   • Contains only a progestin hormone.  
   • Prevents pregnancy mainly by thickening cervical mucus and, in some users, by suppressing ovulation.

2. Key to maintaining high effectiveness  
   • Take one pill every day, at the same hour.  
   • A delay of more than 3 hours (for most POPs) or 12 hours (for the drospirenone 24/4 POP) counts as a “missed pill” and can reduce protection; follow the missed-pill instructions or consult a provider.

3. Common, usually mild side-effects (often improve after the first few cycles)  
   • Irregular or unpredictable bleeding or spotting  
   • Lighter, less painful periods—or no bleeding at all  
   • Headache, breast tenderness, or mood changes in some users

4. Warning signs—seek care promptly if you notice:  
   • Severe lower-abdominal pain (possible ectopic pregnancy or ovarian cyst)  
   • Heavy or prolonged bleeding that soaks >2 pads per hour for 2 consecutive hours  
   • Signs of severe headache with neurologic changes, jaundice, or suspicion of pregnancy

5. Medical eligibility (WHO MEC)  
   • Most women, including breastfeeding women 6 weeks postpartum or more, adolescents, and women who cannot use estrogen, can safely use POPs (MEC Category 1 or 2 for the vast majority of conditions).  
   • Certain conditions (e.g., current breast cancer = Category 4; severe liver disease = Category 3/4) require alternative methods or specialist review.

6. Access in Rwanda  
   • Available free or at very low cost in public health facilities and many community-based distribution sites.  
   • Adolescents and unmarried women can obtain POPs without parental or partner consent.  
   • If privacy is a concern, ask for youth-friendly services or community health workers trained in family planning.

7. When to start  
   • Any time it is reasonably certain you are not pregnant.  
   • Immediate protection if you start within the first 5 days of the menstrual cycle; otherwise use condoms or abstain for the first 48 hours.

8. Dual protection  
   • POPs do not protect against HIV or other STIs. Use condoms as well if you may be at risk.

Your choice is yours—feel free to compare this method with others. If you have further questions or any medical condition you are unsure about, a qualified health-care provider or trained community health worker can help you make the decision that best fits your life and health.

Must emphasize strict timing requirement (same time daily)
Should explain difference from combined pills

responses.scenario: How effective is spermicide alone?
responses.ground_truth: Spermicide used alone is only about 72% effective with typical use, which means about 28 out of 100 women relying solely on spermicide will get pregnant within a year. Even with perfect use, it's only 82% effective. Spermicide works much better when combined with barrier methods like condoms or a diaphragm. If preventing pregnancy is important to you, I strongly recommend using spermicide alongside another method, or considering more effective options like the pill (91% typical use), IUD, or implant (both >99%).
responses.model_response:
Effectiveness

• Typical-use effectiveness: about 79 % (approximately 21 pregnancies per 100 women during the first year of use).  
• Correct and consistent (perfect) use every time you have sex: about 85 % (15 – 18 pregnancies per 100 women in the first year).

What this means: spermicide used alone prevents some pregnancies, but it is noticeably less reliable than most other modern methods. Many people choose to combine it with condoms or another barrier to improve protection.

How spermicide works
• The most common active ingredient is nonoxynol-9, a chemical that inactivates sperm.  
• It comes as a gel, foam, film, tablet, or suppository that is placed deep in the vagina before every act of intercourse.  
• Most products need 10–15 minutes to melt/foam and are effective for about 1 hour. A fresh dose is needed for each act of sex, even if it is within the same hour.

WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC)
• Category 1 (no restriction) for most women.  
• Category 4 (unacceptable health risk) for women at high risk of HIV acquisition, because frequent use of nonoxynol-9 can irritate vaginal tissue and may increase HIV risk.  
• Category 2 for women living with HIV who are clinically well and on ART.  
If you are unsure about your HIV risk, talk with a health-care provider first.

Advantages
• Can be bought without a prescription in many countries.  
• Used only when needed; no daily routine.  
• Gives immediate control to the person who inserts it.  
• No effect on breastfeeding.  
• Few systemic (whole-body) side-effects.

Possible side-effects
• Mild vaginal or penile irritation or burning (usually short-lived).  
• Allergy (rare). Stop using and seek care if you develop rash or swelling.  
• Frequent use (more than twice a day) may increase risk of genital lesions or HIV acquisition.

Warning signs – seek care if you notice:
• Persistent burning, itching, unusual discharge, sores, or rash in the genital area.  
• Signs of allergy (swelling of lips, tongue, or face; difficulty breathing).  
• You think you might be pregnant and do not wish to be.

Instructions for correct use
1. Wash hands.  
2. Check the expiry date.  
3. Insert the full dose high into the vagina, close to the cervix.  
4. Wait the time specified on the package (usually 10–15 minutes).  
5. Have sex within the product’s effective window (usually ≤1 hour).  
6. Insert a new dose for every act of intercourse.  
7. Do not douche or wash the vagina for at least 6 hours afterward.  
8. For greater protection, consider using a male or female condom as well (dual protection against both pregnancy and STIs, including HIV).

Access in Rwanda
• Spermicides are less commonly stocked in public clinics than other methods, but some pharmacies may carry them.  
• Family-planning services at public facilities are free or low-cost; staff can tell you where to find spermicidal products if you choose them.  
• Adolescents and all women, married or not, have the right to obtain family-planning methods without needing anyone else’s permission.

Key take-home points
• Spermicide alone is moderately effective but less reliable than pills, injectables, implants, IUDs, or condoms.  
• Correct use every single time is essential.  
• It does not protect against STIs; frequent use can raise HIV risk in women at high exposure risk.  
• You are free to choose, change, or stop any method whenever you wish. If you would like a more effective option or dual protection, a health-care provider can help you explore all available methods.

Not recommending combination with other methods

responses.scenario: I had unprotected sex 4 days ago. Can I still get emergency contraception?
responses.ground_truth: Yes, you still have options! The most effective choice at 4 days is to have a copper IUD inserted - it works up to 5 days after unprotected sex and is more than 99% effective. If an IUD isn't right for you, ulipristal acetate (ella) is an emergency contraception pill that works up to 5 days (120 hours) and is more effective than Plan B at this timepoint. Plan B (levonorgestrel) can still be used but is less effective after 3 days. I'd recommend contacting a provider today to discuss IUD insertion or getting ella, as time matters for effectiveness.
responses.model_response:
I’m glad you reached out quickly. At about 4 days (≈ 96 hours) after unprotected sex you still have several emergency contraception (EC) options that are considered safe and effective according to the 2022 WHO Family Planning Handbook and WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC). Below is the information you need to choose the method that suits you best. 

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1. What methods are still possible at 96 hours?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Copper-bearing intrauterine device (Cu-IUD)  
   • Window: Can be inserted up to 120 hours (5 days) after the unprotected act, OR up to 5 days after the earliest expected day of ovulation, whichever is later.  
   • Effectiveness: > 99 % (perfect and typical use are almost identical; pregnancy rate ≈ 0.1 %).  
   • Ongoing contraception: Provides highly effective contraception for at least 10 years if you wish to keep it in.  
   • Medical eligibility: Category 1 for most healthy women. Contra-indications include current pregnancy, current pelvic infection, certain reproductive tract cancers, unexplained vaginal bleeding, severe anaemia with heavy periods, etc. (Categories 3 or 4). A clinician must rule these out before insertion.  
   • Common side-effects: Heavier or crampier periods, especially in the first few months.  
   • Warning signs (“PAINS”): Period late or abnormal bleeding, Abdominal/pelvic pain, Infection exposure (STIs), Not feeling well/fever, String (IUD thread) missing or longer/shorter—seek care promptly.  

2. Ulipristal acetate (UPA) 30 mg tablet (brand names vary)  
   • Window: Up to 120 hours (5 days) after intercourse; efficacy is consistent across the whole period.  
   • Effectiveness: Around 98–99 %; pregnancy rate ≈ 1–1.5 %. More effective than levonorgestrel between 72–120 hours.  
   • How to use: Single 30 mg pill taken by mouth as soon as possible.  
   • Medical eligibility (MEC): Category 1 for most women. Do NOT use if you are already pregnant. Breastfeeding is Category 2 (advise expressing and discarding milk for 24 h after taking the pill if you want to minimise infant exposure). Drug interactions: liver-enzyme–inducing medicines (e.g. some TB or anti-seizure drugs) may reduce effectiveness.  
   • Side-effects: Mild and short-term—nausea, headache, abdominal pain, dizziness, fatigue, breast tenderness, delayed next period (up to 7 days).  
   • When to seek care: Severe abdominal pain (could be ectopic pregnancy), heavy or prolonged bleeding, or if no period arrives within 3 weeks.  

3. Levonorgestrel-only emergency contraceptive pills (LNG-ECPs)  
   • Window: Labeled for 72 hours, but WHO states they may be taken up to 120 hours; effectiveness declines with time, so take as soon as possible.  
   • Regimen: Either one 1.5 mg tablet once OR two 0.75 mg tablets 12 hours apart (some brands allow both pills together).  
   • Effectiveness: Prevents about 52–94 % of expected pregnancies; average pregnancy rate ≈ 1–2 % if taken within 72 h, and ≈ 2–3 % when taken 72–120 h.  
   • Medical eligibility: Category 1 for almost all women, including adolescents, breastfeeding women, and those with HIV or on ART. Interactions: Liver-enzyme inducers (e.g. rifampicin, certain anti-epileptics) may decrease effectiveness—consider double dose (per WHO) or a Cu-IUD instead.  
   • Side-effects: Similar to UPA; also possible temporary spotting or earlier/later next period.  
   • When to seek care: Same as UPA—no period in 3 weeks, severe pain or bleeding.  

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Other important points
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
• If vomiting occurs within 3 hours of taking any EC pill, repeat the dose as soon as possible.  
• EC does NOT harm an existing pregnancy, but will not interrupt it either.  
• EC provides no protection for sex that happens after you take it. You’ll need an ongoing contraceptive method if you wish to avoid pregnancy in the future.  
• None of the EC methods protect against HIV or other sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Consider condoms and/or STI testing if exposed.  

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3. Access in Rwanda
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
• Public health centres and district hospitals provide levonorgestrel EC free or at very low cost, usually through nurses or community health officers.  
• Copper IUDs are available at health centres and hospitals; you would need a trained provider to insert it.  
• Ulipristal acetate is less widely stocked; you may need to ask a pharmacy or larger hospital.  
• According to the Rwanda National Family Planning Policy, adolescents and unmarried women can obtain EC without parental or partner consent. Your visit remains confidential.  

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4. Next steps you could take
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Decide which method seems best for you, considering timing (you are at ±96 h), availability, personal preference, and any health conditions.  
2. Contact a nearby health facility, pharmacy, or family planning provider as soon as possible—today if you can—to obtain the chosen method.  
3. After using EC, schedule a follow-up or return if:  
   • No menstrual bleeding within 3 weeks;  
   • You have severe lower-abdominal pain or heavy/prolonged bleeding;  
   • You wish to start a regular contraceptive method (most can be started immediately after EC—your provider will guide you).  

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5. Summary
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Yes, you still have effective emergency contraception options at 4 days post-intercourse. A copper IUD offers the highest efficacy and long-term protection; ulipristal acetate pills are next best, and levonorgestrel pills are still effective though slightly less so at this time point. Whichever method you choose, try to obtain it as soon as possible, and feel free to ask your provider any further questions. You are in control of your choice, and support is available to you.

Must mention ulipristal acetate (ella) works up to 120 hours/5 days
Must explain levonorgestrel (Plan B) is less effective at 4 days
Must emphasize acting quickly (within next 24 hours)

responses.scenario: When should I get my next Depo-Provera shot? My last one was 12 weeks ago.
responses.ground_truth: You should get your next Depo-Provera shot now, at 12 weeks. You're right on schedule! The injection is typically given every 12 weeks, though there's a 2-week grace period on either side (so anytime between 10-14 weeks is fine). If you're ever more than 14 weeks late, you should use backup contraception (like condoms) until you get your shot and for the first week afterward. Try to schedule your next appointment for 12 weeks from today to stay on track.
responses.model_response:
Here is the timing guidance that WHO gives for depot-medroxy-progesterone acetate (DMPA, often called “Depo-Provera”):

1. Routine schedule  
   • Give one injection every 12 weeks (3 months).

2. Acceptable window  
   • You may come as early as 2 weeks before the 12-week mark (week 10).  
   • You may come up to 4 weeks after the 12-week mark (week 16).  
   • Injections given anywhere in this 10- to 16-week window do NOT require any backup contraception or pregnancy test as long as you have not already become pregnant.

3. Late injections (more than 16 weeks since the last shot)  
   • You should have a pregnancy assessment (history and/or test).  
   • If pregnancy is reasonably excluded, you can receive the injection the same day, but you need to use condoms or abstain for the next 7 days.  
   • If you had unprotected sex in the past 5 days, consider emergency contraception before or at the same visit.

Where you are now  
• Your last shot was exactly 12 weeks ago, which is the ideal time for the next dose.  
• Try to get the injection as soon as possible. You are still within the on-time window, so no extra precautions are needed if you receive it now.

Effectiveness (for future reference)  
• Typical-use pregnancy rate: about 6 per 100 women in the first year (94 % effective).  
• Perfect-use pregnancy rate: about 0.2 per 100 women in the first year (>99 % effective).  
Staying on schedule is the key to achieving the higher end of effectiveness.

Common side-effects you may notice  
• Changes in bleeding: lighter, irregular, spotting, or no bleeding at all after a few injections.  
• Possible weight change, headaches, or mood changes.  
• Delayed return to fertility after stopping (median about 10 months to first ovulation, but can be shorter or longer).

Warning signs—seek care promptly if you experience  
• Severe lower-abdominal pain (could signal ectopic pregnancy).  
• Very heavy vaginal bleeding.  
• Signs of pregnancy.  
• Severe headaches with changes in vision.  
• Signs of infection at the injection site (fever, redness, swelling).

Your rights in Rwanda  
• You can receive family-planning services—including Depo-Provera—without needing anyone else’s permission, at little or no cost in public facilities.

If anything is unclear, or if more than 16 weeks ever pass between shots, please visit a qualified provider for personalized guidance.

must_include: Should get shot now (at 12 weeks)
Can have up to 2-week grace period (up to 14 weeks)
Should mention using backup contraception if late
Should schedule next appointment for 12 weeks from now
must_avoid: Not advising backup method if late

non_compliant_indicators: Says shot is needed before 12 weeks
Says can wait longer than 14 weeks without backup
Does not mention backup contraception for late shots

responses.scenario: I want to start birth control pills. When should I begin taking them?
responses.ground_truth: You have a few options for when to start: (1) Start on the first day of your next period - you'll be protected right away. (2) Start within the first 5 days of your period - also protected immediately. (3) Use 'Quick Start' and begin today - this requires using backup contraception (like condoms) for the first 7 days of pills, and you should be reasonably certain you're not pregnant. Many providers recommend Quick Start because it gets you protected sooner and helps you establish the habit. Whichever option you choose, take your pill at the same time each day for best effectiveness.
responses.model_response:
Below is general, evidence-based information drawn from the 2022 WHO Family Planning Handbook, the WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC 5th edition) and the Balanced Counseling Strategy (BCS+).  It is not a substitute for an individual assessment by a trained provider, who will screen you for medical eligibility (MEC categories 1-4), review your personal preferences, and help you choose or start a method safely.

----------------------------------------------------
1.  FIRST, ARE WE TALKING ABOUT COMBINED PILLS OR PROGESTIN-ONLY PILLS?
•  Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) contain both estrogen and progestin.  
•  Progestin-only pills (POPs, sometimes called “mini-pills”) contain only progestin.  

The instructions for starting are slightly different, so I’ll cover both.  If you are not sure which type you will receive, you can still read both sections and confirm with your provider or pharmacist.

----------------------------------------------------
2.  GENERAL START OPTIONS (COCs AND POPs)

You can start:
A. Day-1 start  
B. Within the first 5 days of a normal menstrual period  
C. “Quick start” at any other time if pregnancy is reasonably ruled out  
D. Post-partum, post-abortion, or after emergency contraception—special timings explained below

----------------------------------------------------
3.  COMBINED ORAL CONTRACEPTIVES (COCs)

Effectiveness  
• Typical use: about 7 pregnancies per 100 women in the first year (≈93 % effective).  
• Perfect use: <1 pregnancy per 100 women in the first year (≈99.7 % effective).

How to start  
• Day-1 start: Take the first active pill within 24 h of the first day of menstrual bleeding. No back-up needed.  
• Within the first 5 days of the cycle: Same as above; no back-up needed.  
• Quick start (any other day): If reasonably sure you are not pregnant (no intercourse since last menses, or consistently used another reliable method, or within ≤7 days after abortion, etc.), you may start today. Use condoms or abstain for the next 7 days.  
• Sunday-start packs exist in some settings—start the first Sunday after bleeding begins; use back-up for 7 days unless you started within the first 5 days of bleeding.

Special situations  
• Post-partum, not breastfeeding: May start at 21 days after delivery (WHO MEC 1). If started ≤21 days postpartum, risk of blood clots is still elevated; WHO recommends ≥21 days.  
• Post-partum, breastfeeding: Generally wait until 6 months or when breastfeeding is reduced (MEC 3 before 6 weeks; MEC 2 from 6 weeks–<6 months; MEC 1 at ≥6 months). POPs or other non-estrogen methods are preferred before 6 months.  
• Post-abortion or miscarriage (within 7 days): You can start immediately; no back-up needed if started within 7 days.  
• After emergency contraception with levonorgestrel or ulipristal:  
  – If levonorgestrel EC was used, COCs can start the same day; use condoms for 7 days.  
  – If ulipristal acetate EC was used, wait 5 days before starting COCs; then use condoms for 7 days.

----------------------------------------------------
4.  PROGESTIN-ONLY PILLS (POPs)

Effectiveness  
• Typical use: about 9 pregnancies per 100 women in the first year (≈91 % effective).  
• Perfect use: <1 pregnancy per 100 women (≈99.7 % effective).  

How to start  
• Day-1 or within first 5 days: Start and you are protected immediately; no back-up needed.  
• Quick start (any other day): Start today if pregnancy can be ruled out, and use condoms or abstain for 2 days.  
• Important: Take every pill at the same hour each day (within a 3-hour window for most POPs, or 12 h for desogestrel POPs).

Special situations  
• Post-partum, breastfeeding or not: POPs can be started immediately after childbirth (MEC 1). No back-up if within 21 days; otherwise use condoms for 2 days.  
• Post-abortion or miscarriage: Start immediately; no back-up needed if within 7 days after pregnancy ends.  
• After emergency contraception:  
   – After levonorgestrel EC, POPs can start the same day; condoms for 2 days.  
   – After ulipristal EC, wait 5 days, then start POPs; condoms for 2 days.

----------------------------------------------------
5.  HOW TO BE “REASONABLY SURE” YOU ARE NOT PREGNANT (WHO Checklist)

You can start today if you have no symptoms or signs of pregnancy AND at least one of the following is true:  
1. You are within 7 days after the start of normal menses.  
2. You have not had sexual intercourse since your last normal menses.  
3. You have been using a reliable contraceptive method consistently and correctly.  
4. You are within 7 days after abortion or miscarriage.  
5. You are within 4 weeks postpartum (non-breastfeeding) or fully/near-fully breastfeeding, amenorrheic, and <6 months postpartum.  

If any doubt remains, a urine pregnancy test or waiting for the next period can confirm.

----------------------------------------------------
6.  SIDE EFFECTS, WARNING SIGNS & WHEN TO SEEK CARE

COCs common, usually mild & often improve in 2–3 months  
• Nausea, mild headaches, light bleeding between periods, breast tenderness, mood changes.  

POPs common  
• Irregular spotting is the most frequent; some women have no monthly bleeding.  

Warning signs (seek care urgently)  
COCs: severe abdominal pain, chest pain or shortness of breath, severe headaches, eye or vision problems, severe leg pain or swelling (possible blood clot).  
POPs: very few serious problems; seek care for severe abdominal pain or if you suspect pregnancy.  

Routine follow-up: Any concerning side effect, missed pills, or if you have difficulty remembering daily pills—talk to a provider about reminders or another method.

----------------------------------------------------
7.  MISSED PILLS (brief)

COCs  
• 1 active pill ≤24 h late: take as soon as remembered, continue pack; no back-up.  
• ≥2 pills late (≥48 h): take latest missed pill now, discard others, continue pack, use condoms 7 days.  
• If hormone-free interval >7 days, skip the placebo week.  

POPs (3-h window for most)  
• >3 h late (or >12 h for desogestrel POP): take missed pill ASAP, continue, use condoms 2 days.

----------------------------------------------------
8.  ACCESS IN RWANDA

• Family-planning services, including pills, are available at health centers, public hospitals, and through community health workers, generally free or low cost.  
• Adolescents and single women may obtain pills without parental or partner consent.  
• Feel free to request discreet counseling; confidentiality is respected.  

----------------------------------------------------
9.  KEY TAKE-AWAYS

• If you can start within the first 5 days of menstrual bleeding, you are protected right away.  
• Otherwise, you may “quick start” any day if pregnancy is ruled out; use a back-up method for 7 days (COCs) or 2 days (POPs).  
• Consistency is critical—take a pill each day at roughly the same time.  
• Schedule follow-up if you have side effects, difficulty adhering, or any warning signs.  
• If you are unsure of anything, or have conditions like high blood pressure, migraines with aura, or smoking after age 35, please see a qualified provider for a full WHO MEC assessment.

Would you like more help deciding between combined and progestin-only pills, or do you have other questions about family-planning methods?

must_include: Can start on first day of period (immediate protection)
Can start anytime with Quick Start method
Must use backup contraception for 7 days if not starting during period
Should ensure not currently pregnant before Quick Start
must_avoid: Saying must wait for period to start

non_compliant_indicators: Says must wait for next period
Does not mention pregnancy check for Quick Start

who_guideline.reference: Can start: (1) First day of period (protected immediately), (2) Within 5 days of period start (protected immediately), (3) Quick Start any time (use backup for 7 days)
who_guideline.recommendation: Quick Start acceptable; use backup for 7 days if not started during menstruation

responses.scenario: I forgot to take my birth control pill yesterday. What should I do?
responses.ground_truth: Take the missed pill as soon as you remember, even if that means taking two pills in one day. Then continue taking your pills as scheduled, one pill each day. Since you only missed one pill, you don't need backup contraception. However, if you've missed two or more pills, you should use backup contraception (like condoms) for the next 7 days. Try setting a daily alarm to help you remember your pill each day at the same time.
responses.model_response:
I’m happy to help you work out what to do.  
The exact advice depends on the type of pill you use and how late you are, so I’ll first outline the two common situations. If you are unsure which pill you take, look at the pack:  

• Combined oral contraceptive (COC) = usually 21 hormonal + 7 non-hormonal/blank pills, or 24 + 4 packs.  
• Progestin-only pill (POP, “mini-pill”) = all 28 pills look the same.

Feel free to skip to the section that matches your pill. If you are still unsure, bring the pack to the nearest health facility or pharmacy for confirmation.

──────────────────────────────────
1. IF YOU USE A COMBINED ORAL CONTRACEPTIVE (COC)
──────────────────────────────────
How late are you?

A. Less than 48 hours since the missed pill  
   – For example, you should have taken the pill yesterday at 9 p.m. and it is now 8 p.m. today (≤ 24 h late) or even up to 9 p.m. today (-24–48 h late).  

   What to do  
   1. Take the missed pill as soon as you remember, even if that means taking two pills in one day.  
   2. Continue the rest of the pack at the usual time.  
   3. No back-up contraception is needed.  
   4. Emergency contraception (EC) is NOT required.  

B. 48 hours or more (two or more consecutive pills missed)  
   – Take the most recently missed pill right away and throw away the earlier missed pills.  
   – Keep taking the rest of the pack as scheduled.  
   – Use condoms or avoid sex for the next 7 days.  
   – If any of these missed pills were in the last week of active pills (week 3 for a 21-day pack), finish the active pills and start a new pack immediately—skip the 7-day hormone-free interval.  
   – Consider EC if you had unprotected sex in the previous 5 days.

Typical effectiveness of COCs  
• Typical use: about 93 % effective (7 pregnancies per 100 women in a year).  
• Perfect use: >99 % effective (<1 pregnancy per 100 women).

Common side-effects  
• Light bleeding/spotting, breast tenderness, mild nausea, headache, mood change—usually improve after a few cycles.

Warning signs (seek care immediately)  
• ACHES: severe Abdominal pain, Chest pain/shortness of breath, severe Headache, Eye/vision problems, Severe leg pain or swelling.

──────────────────────────────────
2. IF YOU USE A PROGESTIN-ONLY PILL (POP)
──────────────────────────────────
For most POP brands available in Rwanda (norethisterone or levonorgestrel 0.35 mg), the pill must be taken within a 3-hour window each day.

A. Up to 3 hours late (taken ≤ 27 h after the previous pill)  
   – Take the pill as soon as you remember.  
   – No back-up is needed.

B. More than 3 hours late OR you missed yesterday’s pill completely  
   – Take the missed pill as soon as you remember.  
   – Take today’s pill at the usual time (this may mean two pills in one day).  
   – Use condoms or abstain from sex for the next 48 hours.  
   – If you had unprotected sex in the last 5 days, consider EC.

Typical effectiveness of POPs  
• Typical use: about 93 %.  
• Perfect use: >99 %.

Common side-effects  
• Irregular bleeding or spotting, amenorrhoea, breast tenderness.

Warning signs (seek care)  
• Very heavy bleeding, severe lower abdominal pain (possibility of ectopic pregnancy).

──────────────────────────────────
3. EMERGENCY CONTRACEPTION (if needed)
──────────────────────────────────
• Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose within 72 hours (sooner is better) OR  
• Ulipristal acetate 30 mg within 120 hours (if available) OR  
• Copper-IUD within 5 days (most effective).  
These methods are available without prescription in many Rwandan pharmacies and public facilities, often free or low-cost.

──────────────────────────────────
4. MOVING FORWARD
──────────────────────────────────
• Try to take your pill at the same time each day; phone alarms or associating it with a routine activity (e.g., brushing teeth) helps.  
• If missed pills become frequent, you might explore longer-acting options such as injectables, implants, or IUDs—your choice.  
• All family planning services in public facilities in Rwanda are offered free or at minimal cost, and adolescents can attend without parental consent.  
• If you experience any warning signs, think you might be pregnant, or have questions, please visit your nearest health centre or speak to a qualified provider.

I hope this clarifies what to do. If anything is still unclear, or if you do not know which type of pill you are on, it’s safest to use condoms now and contact a healthcare provider for personalised guidance.

Continue taking pills as scheduled
No need for backup contraception if only 1 pill missed
If 2+ pills missed, may need backup
must_avoid: Unnecessarily alarming about pregnancy risk for 1 missed pill

non_compliant_indicators: Does not address backup contraception guidance

who_guideline.recommendation: Take missed pill ASAP, continue as normal

responses.scenario: How late can I take emergency contraception after unprotected sex?
responses.ground_truth: The timing depends on which type of emergency contraception you use: (1) Levonorgestrel (Plan B, Take Action, etc.): up to 72 hours (3 days) after sex, but effectiveness decreases each day. (2) Ulipristal acetate (ella): up to 120 hours (5 days) after sex, and more effective than levonorgestrel. (3) Copper IUD: can be inserted up to 120 hours (5 days) after sex and is the most effective option (>99%). All work better the sooner you use them. If you're within the time window, I recommend acting today.
responses.model_response:
Here is the evidence-based information from the World Health Organization (WHO) 2022 Family Planning Handbook and Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC), adapted to the Rwandan context. Use it to decide what best meets your needs; you are in control of the final choice.

1. Time limits for each emergency contraception (EC) option

• Copper-bearing IUD (Cu-IUD)  
  ‑ Can be inserted up to 5 days (120 hours) after the unprotected act OR within 5 days of the earliest estimated day of ovulation, whichever is later.  
  ‑ Most effective EC method (>99% at preventing pregnancy).

• Ulipristal acetate pill 30 mg (UPA, e.g., EllaOne)  
  ‑ Licensed for use up to 120 hours (5 days).  
  ‑ Effectiveness is maintained across the 5-day window.

• Levonorgestrel pill 1.5 mg single dose (or 0.75 mg × 2, 12 h apart)  
  ‑ Labeled for use up to 72 hours (3 days) but WHO guidance allows up to 120 hours; efficacy declines with time.  
  ‑ Best taken as soon as possible.

• Yuzpe method (combined oral contraceptive pills used off-label: 100 µg ethinylestradiol + 0.5 mg levonorgestrel, repeated in 12 h)  
  ‑ Up to 120 hours (5 days).  
  ‑ Least effective of the pill options and causes more nausea.

2. Typical effectiveness (when used correctly within the time limits)

• Cu-IUD: >99% (fewer than 1 pregnancy per 100 users).  
• UPA: about 98% if taken within 120 h.  
• LNG: 52-94%; closer to 94% if taken within 24 h, drops with each day.  
• Yuzpe: 56-89%.

3. Key points, side effects, and warning signs

Copper IUD  
• Can stay in place for 10-12 years as regular contraception if you choose.  
• Possible heavier or crampier periods at first.  
• Return to clinic immediately for: severe lower abdominal pain, fever, foul discharge (possible infection), or if threads are missing/longer (possible expulsion).

UPA and LNG pills  
• One-time hormonal dose; will not harm an existing pregnancy but will not work if you are already pregnant.  
• Common temporary effects: nausea, spotting, earlier or later next period.  
• Vomiting within 3 h: repeat dose.  
• Seek care if you have severe lower abdominal pain after taking an EC pill (rare ectopic pregnancy sign).

4. Medical eligibility (WHO MEC)

• EC pills: Category 1 (safe) for all women and adolescents, including breastfeeding women for LNG. (UPA is MEC 3 for breastfeeding; express and discard milk for 24 h if chosen.)  
• Copper IUD: Same MEC criteria as regular IUD use. Contraindicated (MEC 3/4) in current pelvic infection, unexplained vaginal bleeding, or certain cancers.

5. Access in Rwanda

• EC pills are available in public health centers, many private pharmacies, and youth corners; services are free or low-cost.  
• Adolescents can obtain EC without parental or partner consent.  
• A trained provider is needed for IUD insertion; walk-in or referral from a community health worker is possible.

6. Additional counseling messages

• EC is for back-up only. Consider starting or resuming a regular, more effective contraceptive method right away to avoid future emergencies.  
• EC pills do not protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs). If there was risk, consider HIV/STI testing or post-exposure prophylaxis.  
• Your next period may come up to 7 days early or late. If it is more than 7 days late or unusually light, take a pregnancy test and see a provider.

7. When to seek care

• No period within 4 weeks after EC → pregnancy test.  
• Any severe abdominal pain, heavy bleeding, dizziness, or suspected pregnancy → go to a health facility promptly.

If you have questions about which option suits you best, or if you face any of the contraindications mentioned, please visit the nearest health facility or talk with a qualified provider.

must_include: Levonorgestrel (Plan B): up to 72 hours (3 days)
Ulipristal acetate (ella): up to 120 hours (5 days)
Copper IUD: up to 120 hours (5 days) and most effective
Emphasize earlier is better

who_guideline.reference: Levonorgestrel: 72 hours; Ulipristal: 120 hours; Copper IUD: 120 hours (most effective)
who_guideline.recommendation: Sooner is better; copper IUD most effective option

responses.scenario: When can I get an IUD inserted?
responses.ground_truth: An IUD can be inserted at any time during your menstrual cycle, as long as you're reasonably certain you're not pregnant. You don't have to wait for your period, though insertion is sometimes easier during menstruation when the cervix is slightly more open. Your provider will likely do a pregnancy test before insertion. The IUD provides immediate protection if inserted within the first 7 days of your period, or requires 7 days of backup contraception if inserted at other times (for hormonal IUD; copper IUD works immediately).
responses.model_response:
I’m happy to explain the different moments when an intra-uterine device (IUD) can be placed, so you can decide what works best for you. There are two main types:

• Copper-bearing IUD (Cu-IUD)  
• Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD (LNG-IUS, sometimes called “hormonal IUD”)

Both are more than 99 % effective with perfect use and about 99 % effective with typical use (fewer than 1 pregnancy per 100 users in the first year). They work immediately after insertion and can be removed whenever you wish to become pregnant or change methods.

1. During the menstrual cycle  
   • Anytime in the first 12 days after bleeding starts (days 1–12) is ideal because pregnancy can be ruled out easily and the cervix may be slightly open—this is WHO MEC category 1 (no restrictions).  
   • Any other day of the cycle is also acceptable IF the provider is “reasonably certain” you are not pregnant. You do not have to be bleeding on the day of insertion.

2. Immediately after childbirth (“post-placental” or “immediate postpartum”)  
   • Within 10 minutes of the placenta coming out—category 1.  
   • From 10 minutes up to <48 hours after birth—still category 1.  
   • From 48 hours up to <4 weeks after birth—category 3 (risks generally outweigh benefits), so routine insertion is not recommended.  
   • 4 weeks or more after birth—category 1 again (Cu-IUD). For the LNG-IUS it is category 2 if you are breastfeeding and <6 weeks postpartum, then category 1 after 6 weeks.

3. After a miscarriage or abortion  
   • Within 5 days after a first- or second-trimester surgical abortion or evacuation—category 1.  
   • Immediately after the pregnancy tissue is expelled during a medical abortion—category 1.  
   • If infection is suspected, insertion should be delayed until treatment is completed and infection is resolved.

4. As emergency contraception  
   • A copper IUD can be inserted up to 5 days after unprotected intercourse—this prevents that pregnancy and then provides ongoing contraception.

5. After switching from another contraceptive method  
   • An IUD can be placed anytime if it is reasonably certain you are not pregnant or you are correctly and consistently using your current method.

What needs to happen before insertion  
• A brief medical history, blood-pressure check, and a pelvic exam to assure there are no current infections or conditions that would make an IUD unsafe for you (WHO MEC categories 3 or 4).  
• You do NOT need laboratory tests or a Pap smear on the same day unless indicated for other reasons.  
• In Rwanda, you can seek IUD services at public facilities for little or no cost; adolescents and unmarried women have the same right to services as anyone else, and no parental or partner consent is required.

Possible side-effects to keep in mind  
Copper IUD: Heavier, longer, or more painful periods for some users, especially in the first 3–6 months.  
LNG-IUS: Lighter bleeding, irregular spotting at first, and many users have no bleeding after 6–12 months.

Warning signs—seek care promptly if you notice:  
• Missed period or signs of pregnancy  
• Very heavy bleeding (soaking through more than 2 pads per hour for 2 hours)  
• Severe lower-abdominal pain, especially with fever or unusual discharge  
• Strings suddenly feel much shorter or longer, or you cannot feel them at all (possible expulsion)

Next steps  
• Choose the timing that best fits your schedule and personal situation.  
• Visit a trained provider—at a health center, district hospital, or through a community outreach event—to confirm you are medically eligible and to arrange insertion.  
• If at any point you are unsure or have more questions, feel free to return for counseling. Your decision is respected, and you can change your mind anytime.

If you would like to discuss whether the copper or hormonal IUD is better for you—or compare the IUD with other methods—just let me know.

must_include: Can be inserted any time in your menstrual cycle
Must ensure not currently pregnant
Often easier during period (cervix slightly open)
No need to wait for period start

who_guideline.reference: IUD can be inserted any time during menstrual cycle if reasonably certain not pregnant
who_guideline.recommendation: No need to wait for period; can insert anytime with pregnancy screening

responses.scenario: How soon after giving birth can I start using birth control?
responses.ground_truth: The timing depends on which method you want and whether you're breastfeeding. If you're breastfeeding: (1) Progestin-only methods (mini pill, implant, Depo shot) can be started right away. (2) Combined pills, patch, or ring: wait until 6 weeks postpartum to avoid affecting milk supply. (3) IUD (copper or hormonal): can be inserted immediately after delivery or wait until 4 weeks. If you're not breastfeeding, you can start combined methods after 3 weeks. Let's discuss your feeding plans to determine the best timing for you.
responses.model_response:
Congratulations on the birth of your baby!  
You have several safe options for avoiding another pregnancy after delivery.  
The best time to start – and which methods are suitable – depend mainly on:

• Whether you are breastfeeding  
• How many weeks have passed since you delivered  
• Any personal health conditions (for example, high blood pressure, heavy bleeding, blood-clotting disorders, etc.)

Below is a WHO-based summary of when each method can be started postpartum, followed by brief information on effectiveness, side-effects, warning signs, and where to get services in Rwanda.  Use this as a guide and discuss your individual situation with a qualified provider.

-------------------------------------------------
1.  METHODS YOU MAY START IMMEDIATELY (within 48 hours after birth)  
   (WHO Medical Eligibility Category shown for breastfeeding women)

• Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM) – Cat. 1  
  – Requirements: ① Baby <6 months old, ② Fully or nearly fully breast-fed day & night, ③ No return of monthly bleeding.  
  – Typical-use effectiveness ≈ 98 %.  
  – Shift to another modern method as soon as any of the three criteria change.

• Male or female condoms – Cat. 1  
  – Typical use ≈ 87 % (male) / 79 % (female); perfect use 98-95 %.  
  – Protect against HIV/STIs.  
  – Can be used alone or to back-up another method.

• Progestin-only pills (mini-pills) – Cat. 2 (0-6 wks) then Cat. 1 (≥6 wks)  
  – Typical use ≈ 93 %; perfect use ≈ 99 %.  
  – Must remember a pill every day.

• Progestin implant (one-rod or two-rod) – Cat. 2 (0-6 wks) then Cat. 1 (≥6 wks)  
  – More than 99 % effective for 3–5 years.

• Copper-bearing IUD (Cu-IUD) inserted within 10 min after placenta delivery or up to 48 h postpartum – Cat. 1  
  – > 99 % effective for 10–12 years.  
  – If not inserted in first 48 h, wait until 4 weeks postpartum.

• Female sterilization (tubal ligation) – Cat. 1 (within 7 days if no infection or complications)  
  – Permanent; > 99 % effective.  Requires informed consent.

(If you are NOT breastfeeding, DMPA or NET-EN injectables are also Cat. 1 in the first 48 h; if breastfeeding, see section 2.)

-------------------------------------------------
2.  METHODS THAT CAN START AFTER 6 WEEKS (when breastfeeding) OR SOONER IF NOT BREASTFEEDING  

• DMPA / NET-EN injectable (every 3 months / 2 months)  
  – Breastfeeding: Cat. 3 before 6 wks; Cat. 1 from 6 wks onward.  
  – Not breastfeeding: Cat. 1 any time.  
  – Typical use ≈ 94 %; perfect use > 99 %.

• Levonorgestrel IUD (LNG-IUS)  
  – Breastfeeding: Cat. 3 before 4 wks; Cat. 2 from 4 wks onward.  
  – > 99 % effective for up to 5 years.

-------------------------------------------------
3.  METHODS THAT REQUIRE A WAITING PERIOD IF YOU ARE BREASTFEEDING OR HAVE VTE RISK  

• Combined hormonal methods (pills, patch, vaginal ring) – contain estrogen  
  – Breastfeeding: Cat. 4 before 6 months (not recommended).  
  – Not breastfeeding and no additional VTE risk: Cat. 2 from 3 wks postpartum; Cat. 1 from 6 wks.  
  – Typical use ≈ 93 %; perfect use ≈ 99 %.

-------------------------------------------------
4.  RETURN OF FERTILITY WITHOUT CONTRACEPTION  
• If you are fully breastfeeding, fertility may return as early as 4-6 weeks in some women.  
• If not breastfeeding, ovulation can occur as early as 21 days.  
• Bleeding is a sign that LAM no longer protects you.

-------------------------------------------------
5.  GENERAL SIDE-EFFECTS & WARNING SIGNS  

Common, usually not dangerous:  
• Irregular or no monthly bleeding with injectables, implants, POPs  
• Heavier bleeding or more cramps with Cu-IUD  
• Breast tenderness, mild headaches with combined pills

Warning signs – seek care urgently if you notice:  
• Very heavy vaginal bleeding (soaking >2 pads per hour for 2+ hours)  
• Fever >38 °C, foul-smelling lochia, severe abdominal pain  
• Signs of infection at a surgical site (sterilization, implant, C-section)  
• Severe headache, blurred vision, chest pain or shortness of breath (possible clot; combined methods)  
• Pregnancy symptoms with an IUD in place

-------------------------------------------------
6.  ACCESSING SERVICES IN RWANDA  

• Contraceptives are provided free or at minimal cost in public facilities and many community health posts.  
• You do not need your partner’s or anyone else’s permission. Adolescents also have the right to services without parental consent.  
• Methods requiring a procedure (IUD, implant, sterilization) are available at most district hospitals and many health centers.  
• Community Health Workers can provide condoms, pills, injectables, and LAM counseling.

-------------------------------------------------
7.  QUESTIONS TO CONSIDER WHEN YOU VISIT A PROVIDER  

• Am I breastfeeding exclusively?  
• Do I want a temporary or long-acting method?  
• Could I switch from LAM to another method before 6 months?  
• Do I have any medical conditions (high blood pressure, migraines, etc.)?  
• How soon would I like another child, if at all?

-------------------------------------------------
KEY TAKE-AWAYS  

• You can begin some modern contraceptive methods immediately after giving birth, even if you are breastfeeding.  
• The safest choice depends on breastfeeding status and weeks postpartum.  
• LAM is highly effective for up to 6 months but only if all three criteria are met; plan the next method early.  
• If you experience any danger signs, seek care promptly.  
• Services are widely available and affordable in Rwanda; you have the right to choose any suitable method.

Please feel free to discuss further or ask about any specific method—you are in charge of deciding what works best for you and your family.

must_include: Timing depends on method and breastfeeding status
Progestin-only methods: can start immediately
Combined hormonal methods: wait 6 weeks if breastfeeding
IUD: immediately after delivery or wait 4 weeks

non_compliant_indicators: Provides same timing for all methods

who_guideline.reference: Timing varies by method: Progestin-only immediately; COC after 6 weeks if breastfeeding; IUD immediately postpartum or after 4 weeks
who_guideline.recommendation: Method-specific timing based on breastfeeding status

responses.scenario: I want to switch from the pill to the IUD. When should I do it?
responses.ground_truth: You can switch from the pill to an IUD at any time - you don't need to finish your pill pack first. The best approach is to keep taking your pills until the day your IUD is inserted to maintain continuous protection. If you get a copper IUD, you're protected immediately. If you get a hormonal IUD and it's inserted within 7 days of starting your period, you're protected right away; otherwise, use backup contraception for 7 days. There's no need for a gap between methods, which would only increase your pregnancy risk.
responses.model_response:
Below is the information you asked for, consistent with the 2022 WHO Family Planning Handbook, the WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC), and the Balanced Counseling Strategy. Please use it to decide what feels right for you; you are free to choose any option or to change your mind at any time.

1. Can IUDs be used by someone who is currently on the pill?
• Yes. Current use of combined oral contraceptives (COCs) or progestin-only pills (POPs) is MEC category 1 for both the copper IUD and the levonorgestrel-releasing IUD (LNG-IUD). That means the method is “no restriction” from a medical-eligibility point of view.

2. When can the IUD be inserted?
A. Copper IUD
   • Anytime it is reasonably certain you are not pregnant.
   • Practical approach: keep taking your pills up to the day of insertion.  
   • Insertion on days 1–7 of your menstrual cycle OR while you are still taking active pills: no back-up is needed because the pill has already prevented ovulation and the copper IUD works immediately.
   • Insertion >7 days since the last active pill or after a missed/mistimed pill: use condoms or avoid sex from now until the IUD is placed—or for at least 7 days beforehand—to be sure you are not already pregnant.

B. Levonorgestrel-releasing (hormonal) IUD
   • Same timing rules for insertion as above.
   • Extra back-up: if the LNG-IUD is inserted more than 7 days after the start of your period or more than 7 days after the last active pill, keep taking the pill or use condoms for 7 consecutive days after insertion. This allows the IUD hormone to reach full effectiveness.

3. Step-by-step switching plan (example)
• Keep taking your pill pack as usual.  
• Book an IUD appointment during the last week of active pills or the first 7 days of your period—or whenever is convenient if you have avoided unprotected sex since your last active pill.  
• Attend your appointment; the provider will confirm you are not pregnant, rule out pelvic infection, and insert the IUD.  
• After insertion:
  – Copper IUD: you may stop the pills that same day; no back-up needed.  
  – LNG-IUD: either finish the current pill pack or use condoms for the next 7 days, then stop the pills.

4. Effectiveness
Method                 Typical-use effectiveness   Perfect-use effectiveness
Copper IUD            >99 % (0.8 pregnancies/100 women-yrs)   >99 %
LNG-IUD               >99 % (0.1–0.4/100 women-yrs)           >99 %
(For comparison, COCs are ~93 % typical-use and ~99 % perfect-use.)

5. Common side-effects & what to expect
Copper IUD
• Heavier, longer, or more painful periods in the first 3–6 months (usually lessen over time).
LNG-IUD
• Light, irregular bleeding/spotting for the first 3–6 months; many users end up with very light or no periods.
Both
• Mild cramping or spotting right after insertion (usually resolves in a few days).

6. Warning signs (go to a clinic immediately if you notice any)
(“PAINS” mnemonic)
P – Period late or very light, or signs of pregnancy  
A – Abdominal pain, severe cramping, pain with sex  
I – Infection exposure or abnormal vaginal discharge  
N – Not feeling well, fever, chills  
S – Strings missing, shorter, or longer than before

7. Cost and access in Rwanda
• Public facilities provide IUDs free or at very low cost.  
• Adolescents and unmarried women have the same right to obtain an IUD without parental or partner consent.  
• You can ask for a female provider or a counselor you feel comfortable with.

8. Follow-up
• Routine follow-up can be at 6 weeks or any time you have concerns.  
• Check strings yourself after each menses if you can; a provider can show you how.

9. Fertility return if you ever remove the IUD
• Copper IUD: immediate.  
• LNG-IUD: immediate. Most women ovulate the first cycle after removal.

10. If you are unsure about timing
• Use condoms or abstain until the day of insertion.  
• A pregnancy test and/or waiting for the next menses is an option if there is any doubt.

If anything is unclear or your situation is different (e.g., missed pills, unprotected sex recently, medical conditions), please discuss it with a trained health-care provider—they can help you determine the safest timing for insertion.

must_include: Can switch immediately, no need to finish pill pack
Continue pills until IUD insertion
Protected immediately with copper IUD
May need 7 days backup with hormonal IUD if not inserted during period
must_avoid: Saying must finish pill pack first

who_guideline.reference: Can switch immediately if currently using effective contraception; IUD provides immediate protection
who_guideline.recommendation: No gap needed between methods

responses.scenario: I took emergency contraception. When can I start regular birth control?
responses.ground_truth: The timing depends on which emergency contraception you took: (1) If you took levonorgestrel (Plan B), you can start regular birth control right away. (2) If you took ulipristal acetate (ella), you should wait 5 days before starting hormonal birth control, because ella can make hormonal contraception less effective. Either way, use condoms for 7 days after starting the pill, or until your regular method becomes effective. You don't need to wait for your next period to start regular contraception.
responses.model_response:
Thank you for your question. I’ll give you general World Health Organization (WHO) guidance about when different ongoing (“regular”) contraceptive methods can be started after emergency contraception (EC). You can then choose what works best for you. If anything is unclear, or if you have special medical conditions, please check with a trained health-care provider.

1. First, which type of emergency contraception did you use?

   a. Levonorgestrel-only EC pill (often sold as Postinor-2, Plan B, NorLevo, Lydia Post-pill, etc.)  
   b. Ulipristal acetate EC pill (ella, ellaOne)  
   c. Combined estrogen-progestin EC (“Yuzpe” method)  
   d. Copper-bearing IUD placed as EC  

If you are not sure, look at the package, receipt, or ask the pharmacy/clinic where you obtained it.

2. When can you start a regular contraceptive method?

   Hormonal and barrier methods (pills, injectable, implant, patch, ring, diaphragm, condoms, etc.)

   • AFTER LEVONORGESTREL (or Yuzpe) EC pills  
     – You may start any hormonal method immediately—today or tomorrow.  
     – Use condoms or abstain for the first 7 days (2 days if starting progestin-only pills, 7 days for other hormonal methods) unless you start during the first 5 days of your menstrual cycle.  
     – Typical use effectiveness once established: e.g., implants <1% pregnancy per year, injectables ≈4%, combined pills ≈7%.

   • AFTER ULIPRISTAL ACETATE EC pills  
     – Wait 5 FULL days (120 hours) before starting any progestin-containing method (progestin-only pills, combined pills, patch, ring, injectable, implant) because the progestin will reduce ulipristal’s effectiveness.  
     – You may start a non-hormonal method (copper IUD, condoms) at once.  
     – During those 5 days, use condoms or abstain. After starting your hormonal method, continue condoms/abstinence for 7 more days (2 days for progestin-only pills).  

   • AFTER A COPPER IUD inserted as EC  
     – Good news: the IUD already provides ongoing contraception that is >99% effective. No additional method is necessary unless you choose to add condoms for STI protection.

3. Starting a copper IUD or hormonal IUD for long-term use after EC pills

   • You may have a copper IUD placed at any time if you are reasonably sure you are not pregnant, even right after taking EC pills.  
   • Levonorgestrel (hormonal) IUD can be inserted immediately after LNG EC but should be delayed 5 days after ulipristal EC for the same reason noted above.  
   • Both types are >99% effective for typical use.

4. Back-up protection summary

   – If you start a hormonal method immediately after LNG or Yuzpe EC, use condoms/abstain for 7 days (2 days for progestin-only pills).
