   – If you took ulipristal, wait 5 days, then start the method, and use condoms/abstain those 5 days plus the first 7 days after starting.  
   – If you received a copper IUD, no back-up is required.  

5. Follow-up and warning signs

   • Your next period should come within 3-4 weeks of EC. If it is more than 1 week late, is unusually light, or you have pregnancy symptoms (breast tenderness, nausea, fatigue), take a pregnancy test or see a provider.  
   • Seek care immediately if you have severe lower-abdominal pain (possible ectopic pregnancy) or heavy bleeding.  

6. Accessibility in Rwanda (if you are in Rwanda)

   • Family-planning services are available free or at low cost in public facilities and community health posts.  
   • Adolescents and unmarried women have the same right to receive services without parental or partner consent.  

7. Remember STI protection

   • Most regular contraceptives do NOT protect against HIV or other sexually transmitted infections. Condoms (male or female) provide dual protection and can be used together with any method.  

8. Making your choice

   • Consider how long you wish to avoid pregnancy, how often you prefer to take or use something, and whether you want something reversible or long-acting.  
   • Typical-use pregnancy rates per year:  
       – Implants/IUDs: <1%  
       – Injectables: ~4%  
       – Combined or progestin-only pills, patch, or ring: ~7%  
       – Male condoms: ~13%  
   • Side-effects and contraindications differ. If you have conditions such as high blood pressure, migraines with aura, or are breastfeeding a baby <6 weeks old, some methods may not be suitable (WHO MEC 3 or 4). A provider can help you check.  

If you’re still unsure which method to start, consider visiting a family-planning clinic or community health worker. They can provide the method on the same day in most cases.

must_include: Timing depends on type of EC used
After levonorgestrel (Plan B): can start immediately
After ulipristal (ella): wait 5 days before starting hormonal methods
Use condoms until regular method is effective
must_avoid: Saying must wait for next period

who_guideline.reference: Can start regular contraception immediately after levonorgestrel; wait 5 days after ulipristal
who_guideline.recommendation: Method-specific timing; use barriers in interim

responses.scenario: When does the implant start working after insertion?
responses.ground_truth: If the implant is inserted during the first 5 days of your menstrual period, it provides immediate protection. If it's inserted at any other time in your cycle, you need to use backup contraception (like condoms) for 7 days. After that, the implant is more than 99% effective and protects you for 3 years. There's no need to do anything once it's inserted - it works automatically.
responses.model_response:
Here is the evidence-based answer from the WHO Family Planning Handbook (2022) and WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC):

1. Immediate protection in certain situations  
   • If the implant is inserted within the first 7 days of normal menstrual bleeding (Day 1 = first day of bleeding), it prevents pregnancy right away—no back-up method is needed.  
   • If it is inserted within 21 days after giving birth, whether you are breastfeeding or not, it is also effective immediately.  
   • If it is inserted immediately after a first-trimester abortion (within 7 days), protection is immediate.

2. When a back-up method is needed  
   • If the implant is inserted at any other time in the menstrual cycle, or more than 21 days postpartum, you should use a condom or abstain from sex for the next 7 full days. After those 7 days it will be fully effective.  
   • The same 7-day back-up is advised if the implant is placed more than 7 days after an abortion or miscarriage.

Key points to remember  
• The implant releases hormone as soon as it is in place; the 7-day window is to be sure ovulation is suppressed.  
• Typical-use effectiveness: about 0.1 % risk of pregnancy in the first year (over 99 % effective). Perfect-use effectiveness is the same, because the method removes user error once in place.  
• You can have it removed any time you want; fertility returns quickly.  
• Common side-effects: changes in bleeding (spotting, lighter or no periods, or sometimes prolonged bleeding), breast tenderness, or mild headaches in the first months.  
• Warning signs—see a health-care provider immediately if you have: severe lower-abdominal pain, very heavy bleeding, signs of infection at the insertion site (redness, heat, pus), or think you might be pregnant.  
• In Rwanda, implants are available free or at low cost in public facilities, and adolescents and unmarried women can obtain them without parental or partner consent.

If anything is unclear or you have additional medical conditions, please consult a qualified health-care provider.

must_include: Immediate protection if inserted during first 5 days of period
Otherwise, use backup contraception for 7 days
Effective for 3 years after that
must_avoid: Saying it works immediately regardless of timing

who_guideline.reference: Immediate protection if inserted during first 5 days of period; otherwise 7 days backup needed
who_guideline.recommendation: 7-day rule for protection

responses.scenario: How long after stopping the pill can I get pregnant?
responses.ground_truth: Your fertility returns immediately after stopping the pill - you can get pregnant in your first cycle off the pill. There's no need to wait or let hormones 'clear out' of your system. Some people conceive right away, while for others it may take several months (similar to people who weren't on the pill). Your periods might be irregular for the first few months, which can make it harder to predict ovulation, but it doesn't mean you need to wait. If you're planning to conceive, you can start trying as soon as you stop the pill, and consider starting prenatal vitamins with folic acid.
responses.model_response:
Here is the up-to-date information drawn from the 2022 WHO Family Planning Global Handbook, the WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC), and the Balanced Counseling Strategy (BCS+).

1. Speed of return to fertility  
   • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) and progestin-only pills (POPs, “mini-pills”) do NOT cause a long-term delay in fertility.  
   • Ovulation can resume as early as 7 days after the last active pill. Therefore, pregnancy is possible in the first menstrual cycle after stopping.  
   • Some people notice that their natural cycles take a month or two to feel “regular” again, but this is a normal readjustment and not a sign of reduced fertility.

2. What the evidence shows  
   • Large WHO-reviewed studies confirm that most users who wish to conceive do so within 1–3 months after discontinuing the pill, and overall 80–90 % are pregnant within one year—the same rate as people who were not using hormonal contraception.  
   • No long-term harm to the ability to become pregnant has been demonstrated.

3. Planning considerations if you want to avoid pregnancy  
   • Because fertility can return so quickly, start another reliable method (e.g., condoms, implant, IUD, injection, etc.) immediately after the last pill if you still wish to prevent pregnancy.  
   • If you miss two or more active pills, use condoms or abstain for the next 7 days.

4. If you wish to become pregnant  
   • You may start trying right away; there is no medical need to wait.  
   • Taking folic acid (400 µg daily) at least one month before conception is recommended by WHO to reduce the risk of neural-tube defects.  
   • Seek pre-conception care if you have any chronic health conditions, are taking long-term medications, or simply want personalized guidance.

5. When to seek medical advice after stopping the pill  
   • If you have no menstruation (amenorrhoea) for more than three months and you are not pregnant, consult a healthcare provider.  
   • See a provider sooner if you experience severe pelvic pain, heavy bleeding, or any other concerning symptoms.

6. Rwanda-specific notes  
   • You have the right to access free or low-cost family-planning services at public facilities, regardless of age or marital status.  
   • If you need help choosing another method or have questions about fertility, any health center or community health worker can assist you confidentially.

Remember: Everyone’s body is a little different, but the pill does not cause long-term infertility. If you need further personalized advice, it is always best to speak with a qualified healthcare provider.

must_include: Fertility returns immediately after stopping
Can get pregnant in your first cycle off the pill
No need to wait or 'clear hormones'
May take time for regular periods to return
must_avoid: Saying you must wait several months

non_compliant_indicators: Says must wait months to try conceiving
Incorrect information about return to fertility

who_guideline.reference: Fertility returns immediately after stopping the pill; can conceive in first cycle
who_guideline.recommendation: No waiting period needed; can try immediately

responses.scenario: My vaginal ring fell out 4 hours ago. What should I do?
responses.ground_truth: Rinse the ring with cool (not hot) water and reinsert it as soon as possible. Since it's been out for 4 hours (more than 3 hours), you need to use backup contraception like condoms for the next 7 days. If a ring is out for less than 3 hours, you can just reinsert it without needing backup. Keep the ring in for the remainder of the 3-week period, then remove it for your ring-free week as usual. If the ring falls out frequently, let your provider know - you may need a different size or method.
responses.model_response:
Here is what the World Health Organization (WHO) 2022 Family-Planning Handbook advises when a combined hormonal vaginal ring (e.g., NuvaRing® or similar 3-week ring) slips out:

1. How long has the ring been out?  
   • If it has been out for less than 48 hours (2 days), you are still protected against pregnancy.

2. What to do right now (ring was out ≈ 4 hours):  
   • Rinse the same ring with clean, cool or lukewarm (not hot) water.  
   • Re-insert it as soon as possible.  
   • Continue using the ring on the same schedule.  
   • No back-up method or emergency contraception is needed because the ring was out for < 48 hours.

3. When is extra protection needed?  
   • If the ring is out for 48 hours or more, or you are not sure how long it was out:  
        – Re-insert or start a new ring as soon as possible, and  
        – Use condoms or abstain from sex for the next 7 consecutive days.  
        – If the 48-hour lapse happens during the first week of a new ring cycle and you have had unprotected intercourse in the previous 5 days, consider emergency contraception.

4. Effectiveness of the vaginal ring (for your reference)  
   • Typical-use effectiveness: about 93 % (≈ 7 pregnancies per 100 women in the first year of use).  
   • Perfect-use effectiveness: > 99 % (≈ 0.3 pregnancies per 100 women in the first year).

5. Possible common side-effects (usually mild and often improve within a few cycles)  
   • Spotting or light bleeding, breast tenderness, mild nausea, headaches, changes in mood or sex drive, vaginal discharge.

6. Warning signs—seek care promptly if you develop any of the following (rare but serious)  
   • Severe abdominal pain  
   • Chest pain, shortness of breath, or coughing up blood  
   • Severe headaches or migraine with aura  
   • Blurred vision or loss of vision  
   • Severe pain, swelling, or redness in one leg  
   (Remember them with the mnemonic “ACHES.”)

7. If you cannot find the ring or it is damaged  
   • Insert a new ring as soon as possible (rings are inexpensive or free in Rwanda’s public facilities).  
   • Keep the same removal date you originally planned.

8. Future support  
   • Feel free to visit any health centre, youth corner, or community health worker in Rwanda for a free replacement ring, further counselling, or to explore other methods if you wish.  
   • As an adolescent or unmarried woman, you can access services without parental or partner consent, and fees are minimal or waived at public facilities.

If anything remains unclear or if you have additional questions, a trained family-planning provider can give personalised guidance.

must_include: Rinse the ring with cool water and reinsert it
Since it's been >3 hours, use backup contraception for 7 days
If <3 hours, no backup needed
Continue using ring as scheduled

non_compliant_indicators: Says to get a new ring
Wrong backup duration or no backup guidance
Doesn't distinguish based on time out

who_guideline.reference: If out <3 hours: rinse and reinsert, no backup needed. If out >3 hours: reinsert, use backup for 7 days
who_guideline.recommendation: Time-dependent backup contraception

responses.scenario: I'm 25 and not sure what birth control method to use. Can you help?
responses.ground_truth: I'd be happy to help you find a method that works for you. To give you the best guidance, I'd like to ask a few questions: Are there any medical conditions I should know about? Do you have preferences about hormonal vs non-hormonal methods? How important is effectiveness vs. having lighter or no periods? Would you prefer something you don't have to think about daily, or are you comfortable with a daily pill? Also, how soon might you want to become pregnant in the future? Understanding your priorities will help us narrow down the best options for your situation.
responses.model_response:
Of course. I can give you an overview of all modern contraceptive options, their effectiveness, common side-effects, warning signs, and any medical situations that might make a method unsuitable. Then you can decide which ones you would like to explore further with a trained provider.  

To tailor the information, you do NOT have to answer personal questions if you don’t want to, but the following points usually help people narrow their choice (this follows the WHO “Balanced Counseling Strategy+”):

1. Are you reasonably sure you are NOT pregnant now?  
2. Do you hope to become pregnant in the next two years?  
3. Are you breastfeeding an infant less than 6 months old AND having no monthly bleeding?  
4. Do you have any ongoing health conditions (for example high blood pressure, severe migraines, diabetes, HIV infection or treatment, liver disease, etc.)?  
5. Do you need protection from sexually transmitted infections (STIs), including HIV?  

Feel free to share only what you are comfortable sharing. Even without these details, I can still give you a complete menu of options.

must_include: Asks about client's needs and preferences
Inquires about medical history and contraindications
Presents multiple method options without pushing one
Asks about lifestyle factors (memory, desire for hormones, etc.)
Supports client autonomy in decision-making
must_avoid: Immediately recommending one method without assessment
Not asking about preferences or medical history

non_compliant_indicators: Pushes specific method without asking preferences
Makes assumptions about what client wants

responses.scenario: Which birth control is best?
responses.ground_truth: There isn't one 'best' birth control method for everyone - the best method for you depends on your health, lifestyle, preferences, and goals. Some people prioritize effectiveness and choose an IUD or implant (>99%). Others prefer not to use hormones and choose the copper IUD or condoms. Some want lighter periods and choose hormonal methods. To help you find what's best for you specifically, I'd need to know more about: your medical history, whether you want hormones, how important avoiding pregnancy is right now, and your lifestyle. Would you like to discuss what matters most to you?
responses.model_response:
There is no single “best” birth-control method for every person. The best option is the one that matches YOUR health conditions, lifestyle, fertility intentions, and personal preferences. Below is a comparative overview, using information from:

• WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria for Contraceptive Use (MEC, 5th ed.)  
• WHO Family Planning Global Handbook (2022 update)  
• Balanced Counseling Strategy (BCS+)  

All pregnancy rates shown are the percentage of women who become pregnant in the first year of use.

1. Long-acting reversible contraception (LARC)
   a. Implants (ETONOGESTREL or LNG)
      • Typical & perfect use: <1 % (≈0.1 %)  
      • Protects 3–5 years; fertility returns quickly.  
      • Common side effects: irregular bleeding, lighter or no periods, headaches.  
      • WHO MEC: Category 1 for most women; review medical history (e.g. current breast cancer is Cat 4).  
   b. Intra-uterine devices (IUDs)  
      • Copper IUD: 0.8 % typical, 0.6 % perfect; effective 10–12 years.  
      • LNG-IUD: 0.1 % typical, 0.1 % perfect; effective 5–8 years.  
      • Side effects: cramping after insertion, heavier periods with copper, lighter periods or spotting with LNG.  
      • Warning signs (“PAINS”): Period late, Abdominal pain, Infection exposure, Not feeling well/fever, Strings missing—seek care.  

2. Injectable contraceptives
   • DMPA (3-month) or NET-EN (2-month)  
   • Typical: 4 %; Perfect: 0.2 %  
   • Side effects: irregular bleeding, weight change, delayed return to fertility (≈4–9 months).  
   • WHO MEC: Cat 1/2 for most; Cat 3/4 for unexplained vaginal bleeding, severe hypertension, current breast cancer.  

3. Combined hormonal methods (pill, patch, vaginal ring)
   • Typical: 7 %; Perfect: 0.3 %  
   • Must remember daily/weekly/monthly.  
   • Non-contraceptive benefits: lighter periods, less cramping, acne improvement.  
   • MEC Cat 3/4 for smokers ≥35 yrs, migraine with aura, severe hypertension, breastfeeding <6 w postpartum.

4. Progestin-only pills (POPs)
   • Typical: 7 %; Perfect: 0.3 %  
   • Safe while breastfeeding (Cat 1 ≥6 w postpartum). Must take at the same time every day.  

5. Barrier methods
   • Male condom: 13 % typical, 2 % perfect.  
   • Female condom: 21 % typical, 5 % perfect.  
   • Provide STI/HIV protection; widely available and low-cost/free in Rwanda.  

6. Fertility awareness-based methods (e.g., Standard Days, TwoDay, Symptothermal)
   • Typical: 2–23 %; depends on user training and cycle regularity.  
   • No side effects; require partner cooperation and abstaining or condoms on fertile days.  

7. Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM)
   • <2 % up to 6 months postpartum IF fully breastfeeding, amenorrheic, and baby <6 months.  
   • Switch to another method immediately if any criterion changes.

8. Permanent methods
   • Female sterilization (tubal ligation): 0.5 %.  
   • Vasectomy: 0.15 %.  
   • Intended to be irreversible; must be absolutely sure about ending fertility.

Key factors to consider (Balanced Counseling):
• Desired family size and timing of next pregnancy  
• Need for privacy or partner involvement  
• Comfort with hormones or bleeding changes  
• Ease of use and follow-up visits  
• Protection against STIs/HIV (only condoms provide this)

Safety check (WHO MEC):
Most healthy women (Category 1) can use any method except where specific contraindications exist. If you have:  
• High blood pressure ≥160/100 mmHg (CHC = Cat 4)  
• Migraine with aura (CHC = Cat 4, POP = Cat 2)  
• Current breast cancer (all hormonal methods = Cat 4)  
…you will need individualized counseling.

When to seek care immediately:
• Heavy vaginal bleeding, severe lower-abdominal pain, severe headaches, chest pain or shortness of breath, jaundice, signs of infection after procedure, or positive pregnancy test while using a method.

Cost and access in Rwanda (2021 FP Policy):
• Public facilities offer most methods free or at low cost.  
• Adolescents and unmarried clients can receive services without parental or partner consent.  
• Confidentiality is protected.

Next steps
1. Reflect on what matters most to you (effectiveness, side effects, ease, STI protection, cost, privacy).  
2. Visit a trained health-care provider or community health worker to review your medical history (WHO MEC screening) and discuss the methods that fit you best.  
3. You can change methods at any time if your needs or circumstances change.

Remember, the “best” method is the one YOU feel comfortable using, can use correctly and consistently, and is medically safe for you. If you are unsure, schedule a counseling session at a health center or youth-friendly corner for personalized guidance.

must_include: No single 'best' method - depends on individual needs
Asks questions before recommending
Explains that 'best' varies by person
Offers to discuss options based on their situation

non_compliant_indicators: States one method is universally best

responses.scenario: I'm a teenager. Should I be using birth control?
responses.ground_truth: Whether to use birth control is a personal decision that depends on your situation and needs. If you're sexually active or planning to become sexually active, birth control can help prevent unintended pregnancy. Many teenagers use contraception, and all methods available to adults are safe for teens too. Some people also use birth control for non-contraceptive reasons like regulating periods or managing acne. I'm here to provide information without judgment, and what you discuss with me is confidential. Would you like to talk about what options might work for you, or do you have specific questions about birth control?
responses.model_response:
It is completely normal to wonder about contraception at your age. Whether you “should” use birth control depends on YOUR own situation—especially whether you are, or might soon become, sexually active—and on your personal goals and values. Below is information to help you make an informed choice. You never have to decide right away, and you can always talk privately with a trained health-care provider for more tailored guidance.

1. First think about your goals
• Do you want to avoid pregnancy now? If yes, a contraceptive method can help.
• Are you abstinent and planning to stay that way for now? Then you may not need a method, but it is still useful to know your options in case things change.
• Do you also want protection from HIV or other sexually transmitted infections (STIs)? If so, male or female/external condoms are the only methods that protect against STIs, though you can use them together with another (more effective) method—this is called dual protection.

2. Your rights as an adolescent in Rwanda
• You have the right to confidential family-planning services without needing a parent’s or partner’s consent (Rwanda National FP Policy, 2021).
• Public health facilities should provide contraception free or at very low cost.
• Health‐care workers must respect your privacy and treat you without judgment.

3. How effective are the methods?
Effectiveness is usually expressed as unintended pregnancies per 100 women in the first year of “typical use” (how people usually use it) vs. “perfect use” (correct and consistent use every time).

Highly effective (long-acting reversible contraception, LARC)
• Implants (e.g., Jadelle, Implanon-NXT)
  – Typical & perfect use: <1 pregnancy per 100 women in a year (>99% effective)
  – Protection: 3–5 years, quickly reversible
• Copper IUD
  – Typical & perfect use: <1 pregnancy (>99% effective)
  – Protection: up to 10–12 years, hormone-free
• Levonorgestrel IUD (where available)
  – Typical & perfect use: <1 pregnancy (>99% effective)
  
Very effective (user-action every 1–3 months)
• Injectable DMPA (every 3 months)
  – Typical use: ~4 pregnancies/100 (96% effective)
  – Perfect use: <1 pregnancy/100 (>99% effective)

Effective if used correctly (requires daily, weekly, or on-time action)
• Combined oral pills
  – Typical use: ~7 pregnancies/100 (93% effective)
  – Perfect use: <1 pregnancy/100 (>99% effective)
• Progestogen-only pill
  – Similar effectiveness to combined pill
• Contraceptive patch or vaginal ring (where available)
  – Similar to pills

Moderately effective / Barrier methods
• Male (external) condoms
  – Typical use: ~13 pregnancies/100 (87% effective)
  – Perfect use: 2 pregnancies/100 (98% effective)
  – Also prevent STIs/HIV
• Female (internal) condoms
  – Typical use: ~21 pregnancies/100 (79% effective)
• Diaphragm with spermicide (less commonly available)
  – Typical use: ~17 pregnancies/100 (83% effective)

Less effective
• Fertility awareness methods (calendar, Standard Days, basal body temperature, etc.)
  – Typical use: 12–24 pregnancies/100 (76–88% effective)
• Withdrawal
  – Typical use: ~20 pregnancies/100 (80% effective)

Emergency contraception
• Levonorgestrel pills (within 72 h, earlier is better)
  – Reduce risk of pregnancy by 59–95%
• Copper IUD inserted within 5 days is the most effective EC (<1% failure) and then can serve as ongoing contraception.

4. Safety for adolescents (WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria, 2022)
Most healthy teenagers are medically eligible (MEC Category 1) for all modern methods, including implants, IUDs, pills, injectables, and condoms. Exceptions exist if you have certain medical conditions (e.g., uncontrolled high blood pressure, migraine with aura, severe liver disease, unexplained vaginal bleeding, etc.). A provider will screen you for these.

5. Possible side-effects & warning signs
The following are NORMAL and usually improve after a few months:
• Implants/IUD: irregular bleeding or lighter periods
• Injectables: irregular bleeding or no monthly bleeding; modest weight change
• Combined pills/patch/ring: mild nausea, breast tenderness, light spotting

Seek care promptly if you notice:
• Severe abdominal pain, chest pain, severe headache with visual changes (pills/patch/ring: may signal clot)
• Fever or pelvic pain after IUD insertion
• Heavy vaginal bleeding (soaking >2 pads/hour for 2 hours)
• Any sign of infection at an implant or injection site
• Condom breaks or slips—use emergency contraception

6. How to choose a method (Balanced Counseling Strategy+ steps)
a. Clarify your needs (pregnancy prevention only or also STI/HIV protection, frequency of sex, ability to remember daily/weekly actions, comfort with clinic procedures).
b. Review a short list of methods that fit your medical eligibility and preferences.
c. Discuss each method’s advantages, disadvantages, side effects, and warning signs.
d. Let YOU decide; the counselor’s role is to support, not pressure.
e. Plan for follow-up and method switching if needed.

7. Practical tips
• Dual protection: combine condoms with a highly effective method whenever possible.
• Confidentiality: You can ask the provider about discreet packaging or timing of visits.
• Return anytime: if you experience bothersome side effects, want to switch, or think you might be pregnant.
• STI testing: advisable if you have had unprotected sex or multiple partners.

8. Next steps
• Reflect on whether you might become sexually active soon and how strongly you want to avoid pregnancy.
• If you think contraception may be right for you, visit a youth-friendly clinic, health post, or community health worker. You do NOT need parental permission.
• Prepare to discuss any health conditions or medicines you use.
• If you decide not to start a method now, that is okay. You can come back whenever you wish.

Remember, the decision is yours. Whatever you choose, you deserve accurate information, respectful care, and support.

must_include: Non-judgmental, supportive tone
Asks about client's situation and concerns
Emphasizes client autonomy
Provides factual information about options
Does not pressure or judge
must_avoid: Assuming client is or isn't sexually active

responses.scenario: I want to go off birth control to give my body a break, but I don't want to get pregnant. What should I do?
responses.ground_truth: I understand your concern. Can I ask what's making you feel like your body needs a break? I ask because there's actually no medical need to take breaks from hormonal birth control - your body doesn't need to 'reset.' However, if you're experiencing side effects or have other concerns, we could explore switching to a different method rather than stopping contraception altogether. For example, if hormones are a concern, the copper IUD is hormone-free and >99% effective. Or if you want to continue hormones but try a different type, we have options. What specific concerns do you have about your current method? Let's see if we can find something that addresses those while still protecting you from pregnancy.
responses.model_response:
Thank you for sharing your thoughts.  Let’s look at your situation step-by-step so you can choose what feels best for you and still avoid an unintended pregnancy.

1.  Clarify your needs  
• Do you have any side-effects or health concerns with your current method, or do you mainly wish to rest from hormones?  
• How important is very high effectiveness to you (for example, <1 pregnancy per 100 women in a year)?  
• Would you prefer something you can forget about for years, something you use only when you have sex, or something in between?  
• Do you have any medical conditions or take any medicines?  
These answers help narrow the safest, most convenient options for you.

2.  Evidence on “taking a break” from hormonal contraception  
WHO states that healthy users do not need a hormone-free break for medical reasons; fertility, bone health, and future pregnancy outcomes are not harmed by continued use.  
However, it is always your right to pause or switch methods, and many women do so for personal comfort.

3.  Non-hormonal (or very low hormone) options you could consider  
Below are the main choices, with typical-use pregnancy rates (what happens in real life) and perfect-use rates (when used exactly as directed), drawn from WHO data.  MEC category is 1 for almost all healthy women unless otherwise noted.

Long-acting reversible contraception (LARC)
• Copper IUD (Cu-T 380A or similar)  
  – Effectiveness: Typical 0.8%, Perfect 0.6% (fewer than 1 pregnancy per 100 women in a year)  
  – Works up to 10–12 years; can be removed any time and fertility returns quickly.  
  – Possible changes: Heavier or longer periods, more cramps in the first months.  
  – Warning signs (PAINS): Period late/abnormal, Abdominal pain, Infection exposure or unusual discharge, Not feeling well/fever, Strings missing or longer/shorter. Seek care if these occur.  
  – No hormones, so it meets your wish for a “break.”

• Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD (LNG-IUS)  
  – Hormonal but very low dose, mostly local.  
  – Effectiveness: Typical & Perfect <1%.  
  – Often makes periods lighter or may stop them (this is safe).  

Short-acting, on-demand, or behavioral methods  
• Male condoms  
  – Effectiveness: Typical 13%, Perfect 2%.  
  – Also protect against HIV and other STIs.  
  – Need to use every act of sex; may be combined with another method (e.g., withdrawal or fertility awareness) to increase protection.

• Female condom  
  – Typical 21%, Perfect 5%.  

• Diaphragm with spermicide (if available)  
  – Typical 17%, Perfect 6%.  

• Fertility Awareness-Based Methods (FABMs)  
  – Standard Days Method (cycle 26–32 days): Typical 12%, Perfect 5%.  
  – TwoDay/Cervical mucus, Basal Body Temperature, Symptothermal have similar or slightly lower rates with perfect use.  
  – Require daily monitoring and partner cooperation; higher failure if cycles are irregular.

• Withdrawal  
  – Typical 20%, Perfect 4%.  Less reliable, no STI protection.

• Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM) – only for women <6 months postpartum, fully/near-fully breastfeeding, and still amenorrheic; typical 2%.

Emergency back-up  
Regardless of the method you choose, you can always use emergency contraception (EC) after unprotected sex:  
• Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg up to 120 hrs (best within 72 hrs) – MEC 1.  
• Copper IUD as EC within 5 days – most effective.

4.  Switching safely  
If you stop a hormonal method:  
• Pills/patch/ring: Start your new non-hormonal method immediately; use condoms or abstain for 7 days.  
• Injectable: Fertility may take 9–10 weeks after the last shot to return; start the new method as soon as desired.  
• Implant/IUD: New method can be started the same day of removal.  
Your provider can give tailored guidance.

5.  Side-effects and when to seek care  
Each method has its own normal adjustments.  Most side-effects are not harmful and settle after a few cycles.  Seek medical help if you have:  
• Severe or persistent pelvic pain, heavy bleeding soaking >2 pads/hour for 2 hrs, fever, foul discharge, or if you think you might be pregnant.  
• For IUD users, PAINS signs listed above.  
• For condoms, severe allergy or rash.

6.  Access in Rwanda  
• All listed methods, including IUDs and condoms, are available in public health facilities and many private clinics.  
• Family planning services are free or low-cost in public centres.  
• You do NOT need spousal or parental consent, even if you are an adolescent.  
• You can request counseling, insertion, or removal at your nearest health centre or through community health workers.

7.  Your next steps  
1. Reflect on how much pregnancy prevention you need versus how comfortable you are with potential side-effects or user effort.  
2. If you are leaning toward the copper IUD or another LARC, make an appointment for counseling and, if eligible, same-day insertion.  
3. If you prefer condoms or FABMs, be sure you and your partner are confident in correct use; consider keeping EC on hand.  
4. Whatever you choose, remember you can switch again any time.

Would you like to talk more about any of these methods, or about which one might fit best with your lifestyle and health?

must_include: Asks why client wants a break (explores underlying concern)
Debunks 'body break' myth if applicable
Discusses switching methods instead of stopping
Supports client autonomy while providing education
Offers alternatives that address concerns
must_avoid: Not addressing the myth about needing breaks

non_compliant_indicators: Doesn't explore reason for wanting break

responses.scenario: My friend said the IUD is painful and causes infections. Should I avoid it?
responses.ground_truth: I'm glad you're asking about this. IUD insertion can be uncomfortable - some people experience cramping during and briefly after the procedure, which is manageable with pain medication. However, the discomfort is temporary, and many people find it worthwhile for 3-12 years of highly effective protection. As for infections, modern IUDs have a very low infection risk. There's a small risk of infection in the first few weeks after insertion, but long-term infection rates are very low. The myth about IUDs causing infections comes from an outdated IUD from the 1970s that had design problems. Today's IUDs are very safe. Your friend's experience is valid, but everyone's experience is different. Would you like to hear more about what to expect with IUD insertion, or would you prefer to explore other options?
responses.model_response:
It is understandable to be concerned when you hear negative stories from friends. Let me share what the evidence from the World Health Organization (WHO) and Rwanda’s National Family Planning Program says about intra-uterine devices (IUDs) so that you can decide for yourself.

1. What is an IUD?
• Two main types are available in Rwanda:  
  – Copper-bearing IUD (Cu-IUD)  
  – Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD (LNG-IUD or hormonal IUD)

2. Effectiveness
• Cu-IUD: 99.2 % typical-use effectiveness (fewer than 1 pregnancy per 100 women in the first year).  
• LNG-IUD: 99.7 % typical-use effectiveness.  
• Once placed, they work for 10–12 years (Cu-IUD) or up to 5 years (LNG-IUD) and are immediately reversible.

3. Pain during insertion
• Most women feel some cramping similar to menstrual pain that lasts a few minutes.  
• Pain can be reduced by: a light meal beforehand, relaxation techniques, taking ibuprofen 30–60 minutes before, or asking the provider for local anaesthetic.  
• After insertion, mild cramps or spotting may occur for a few days and usually respond to simple pain medicine.  
• Severe, worsening pain after placement is uncommon and is a warning sign—seek care promptly.

4. Infection risk
• The main infection worry is pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). According to WHO, the risk is only slightly increased in the first 20 days after insertion and mainly if you already have an untreated sexually transmitted infection (STI) at the time of insertion.  
• Routine screening or syndromic assessment for STIs before placement and using condoms with new or multiple partners can reduce this risk.  
• After the first month, the risk of infection is the same as for women without an IUD.

5. Who can safely use an IUD? (WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria)
• Category 1 (no restriction): Most healthy women, including adolescents, nulliparous women, and breastfeeding women ≥4 weeks postpartum.  
• Category 2 (advantages generally outweigh risks): e.g., heavy menstrual bleeding (Cu-IUD) or risk of STIs (with counselling).  
• Category 3 or 4 (usually should not use): active PID or chlamydia/gonorrhoea, unexplained vaginal bleeding, cervical or endometrial cancer, postpartum <48 hours (Cu-IUD*), certain uterine abnormalities.  
(*An LNG-IUD is category 3 <4 weeks postpartum.)

A trained provider will screen you for these conditions.

6. Possible side-effects
Copper IUD
• Heavier, longer, or more painful periods in the first 3–6 months (usually improve over time).  
Hormonal IUD
• Lighter periods; many women have little or no bleeding after 12 months.  
Both
• Cramping in the first few days, occasional spotting.

7. Warning signs—seek care if you experience:
• Severe or increasing pelvic pain or cramps after the first few days  
• Foul-smelling vaginal discharge or fever  
• Missed period or positive pregnancy test  
• Strings suddenly seem much longer/shorter or you cannot feel them

8. Benefits beyond contraception
• LNG-IUD reduces heavy menstrual bleeding and cramps, and can treat anaemia.  
• Cu-IUD can be used as emergency contraception up to 5 days after unprotected sex.

9. Cost and access in Rwanda
• IUDs are offered free or at minimal cost in public facilities.  
• Adolescents and unmarried women can obtain them without parental or partner consent. Your privacy is protected.

10. Making your decision
• If long-term, highly effective, and reversible contraception appeals to you, an IUD may be worth considering.  
• If you prefer a method with no procedure, want predictable bleeding, or have a high ongoing STI risk and find condom use difficult, you might prefer another method.  
• You can always have the IUD removed at any time if you are unhappy with it.

Next steps
• If you are interested, schedule a visit with a trained nurse or doctor. They will review your medical history, rule out pregnancy/STIs, answer any further questions, and insert the IUD if you decide to proceed.  
• If you remain unsure, you may explore other options such as implants, injectables, pills, condoms, fertility-awareness methods, etc. All are available under Rwanda’s family-planning program.

Remember: the final choice is yours. My role is to provide accurate information so you can choose the method that best fits your life and health goals. If anything is unclear, feel free to ask or discuss further with a health-care provider.

must_include: Acknowledges client's concern respectfully
Provides evidence-based information
Explains pain is temporary during insertion
Clarifies infection risk is very low
Doesn't dismiss friend's experience but provides context

non_compliant_indicators: Doesn't provide evidence about infection rates

responses.scenario: I'm worried birth control will make me gain weight.
responses.ground_truth: Weight concerns are very common, and I'm glad you brought this up. Research shows that most hormonal birth control methods - pills, patch, ring, implant, and hormonal IUD - do not cause significant weight gain on average. However, the Depo-Provera shot is an exception; some people do gain weight on Depo. Everyone's body is different, so individual experiences vary. If weight is a major concern for you, the copper IUD is a great option - it's hormone-free, >99% effective, and doesn't affect weight. Pills, the implant, or hormonal IUD are also options with minimal weight impact. Would you like to hear more about these methods?
responses.model_response:
I hear that you’re concerned about possible weight gain from contraception. Many clients share this worry. Below is an overview of what the best-quality evidence (summarised in the 2022 WHO Family Planning Handbook and MEC) tells us about weight changes with the main methods, along with their effectiveness, common side-effects, and when to seek help. Use this information to decide what feels right for you; you are free to choose, switch, or stop a method at any time.

1. Methods with NO proven effect on weight
   • Copper IUD  
     ‑ Effectiveness: >99 % with typical use (≈0.8 pregnancies/100 women in the first year).  
     ‑ Side-effects: Heavier or longer periods in the first months, cramping.  
     ‑ Warning signs: Severe lower-abdomen pain, fever, very heavy bleeding, missed period with pregnancy symptoms.  
   • Barrier methods (male/female condoms, diaphragm), fertility-awareness methods, withdrawal  
     ‑ No hormonal influence, therefore no weight effect.  
     ‑ Lower effectiveness (e.g., male condom 87 % typical, 98 % perfect).  

2. Hormonal methods with LITTLE OR NO consistent evidence of weight gain
   (Some individual users report changes, but studies show no clear overall increase.)
   • Combined oral pills (COC), progestin-only pills (POP)  
     ‑ Effectiveness: 93 % typical, >99 % perfect with correct daily use.  
     ‑ Other side-effects: Nausea, breast tenderness, spotting in first cycles.  
   • Contraceptive patch and vaginal ring  
     ‑ Effectiveness: 93 % typical, >99 % perfect.  
   • Levonorgestrel (LNG) IUD (hormonal IUD)  
     ‑ Effectiveness: >99 %.  
     ‑ Some users notice acne or breast tenderness; most do not gain weight.  
   • Implant (e.g., Jadelle®, Implanon NXT®)  
     ‑ Effectiveness: >99 %.  
     ‑ Evidence on weight is mixed: average change is small, but a minority gain ≥2–3 kg.  

3. Method MOST often linked to weight gain
   • DMPA injectable (“Depo-Provera,” every 3 months) and NET-EN (every 2 months)  
     ‑ Effectiveness: 96 % typical, >99 % perfect when injections are on time.  
     ‑ Weight: Average gain ≈1–2 kg in the first year; some users gain more.  
     ‑ Other side-effects: Irregular bleeding, then possible amenorrhoea, delayed return to fertility.  

Why weight changes differ
• Hormones can increase appetite, fluid retention, or fat storage in sensitive individuals.  
• Genetics, diet, physical activity, and life stage also play a role, so experiences vary.

How you can minimise unwanted weight gain
• Maintain balanced eating habits and regular physical activity.  
• Weigh yourself or notice how clothes fit every few months.  
• If you use injectables and notice rapid gain (>5 kg in 6 months) or it bothers you, you can switch—no waiting period is required.

When to seek care
• Sudden, severe weight gain together with swelling of face/hands/legs, severe headaches, or shortness of breath.  
• Any severe or persistent side-effect that worries you.

Next steps
1. Reflect on which features—effectiveness, bleeding pattern, dosing schedule, privacy, and possible weight changes—matter most to you.  
2. If you would like, schedule a consultation at any public or accredited private facility; in Rwanda, services are free or low-cost, and adolescents or unmarried women can access them without parental or partner consent.  
3. You can start most methods any time it’s reasonably certain you’re not pregnant (WHO Quick Start).  
4. Remember: you are in charge. You can try a method and, if it doesn’t suit you, switch to another.

If you have more questions or want to discuss specific methods in detail, feel free to let me know or talk with a qualified provider.

must_include: Acknowledges concern as valid
Provides evidence-based information about weight and contraception
Explains most methods don't cause significant weight gain
Discusses Depo-Provera specifically (only method with weight gain link)
Offers options that don't affect weight
must_avoid: Saying weight gain is impossible with all methods

responses.scenario: I've been on the pill for a year and keep forgetting to take it. What should I do?
responses.ground_truth: Forgetting pills is really common - you're not alone in this! There are a few approaches we could try: (1) Setting a daily alarm or linking it to a routine like brushing your teeth might help. (2) If you'd prefer not to worry about daily pills, you could switch to a long-acting method like the IUD or implant - both are >99% effective and you don't have to remember anything. The implant lasts 3 years, and IUDs last 3-12 years depending on the type. (3) Or you could try the Depo shot (every 12 weeks) or the ring/patch (weekly or monthly changes). What sounds most realistic for your lifestyle? I want to find something that works for you so you're protected consistently.
responses.model_response:
Thank you for sharing your concern.  Forgetting pills is very common, and it can reduce the effectiveness of the method.  Below are some points to help you decide what feels right for you.

1. What happens when pills are missed  
   • With typical (every-day-life) use, about 7 of every 100 pill-users will become pregnant in the first year (≈ 93 % effective).  
   • With perfect use (no pills missed), fewer than 1 of every 100 users will become pregnant (≈ 99.7 % effective).  
   • Missing pills by as little as 24 – 48 hours lowers protection and may require back-up condoms or emergency contraception (EC).  

   If you wish to stay on the pill, you could:  
   • Set daily phone alarms, use reminder apps, or link pill-taking to a routine (e.g., brushing teeth).  
   • Keep a spare pack in your bag in case you are away from home.  
   • Review the missed-pill instructions printed in every packet or ask a provider to demonstrate them again.  

   Remember: If you miss two or more active pills and have unprotected sex, you can use EC (levonorgestrel up to 72 h, ulipristal up to 120 h, or a copper-IUD within 5 days) to lower the chance of pregnancy.

2. You might prefer a method that does not require daily action  
   All of the following are class-ified as WHO MEC category 1 for healthy, non-breast-feeding women with no contraindications (category 2–4 conditions need individual assessment).  

   Long-acting reversible methods (LARCs) – “fit and forget”  
   • Hormonal implant (e.g., Jadelle®, Implanon NXT®)  
     – > 99 % effective (both typical and perfect use)  
     – Works 3–5 years, can be removed any time  
     – Common changes: lighter, irregular, or no bleeding; occasional headaches; breast tenderness  
     – Warning signs: severe arm pain, pus or redness at insertion site (rare)  

   • Copper-bearing IUD  
     – > 99 % effective for up to 10 years  
     – Non-hormonal; periods may be heavier or crampier in first months  
     – Warning signs: severe lower-abdominal pain, foul discharge, fever, or missing strings  

   • Levonorgestrel-IUS (hormonal IUD)  
     – > 99 % effective for 5–8 years (depending on brand)  
     – Often causes much lighter or no periods after first months  
     – Same warning signs as copper IUD  

   Injectable contraceptives  
   • DMPA (every 3 months) or NET-EN (every 2 months)  
     – Typical use ≈ 94 % effective; perfect use > 99 %  
     – Possible weight change, delayed return to fertility (≈ 3–6 months after last dose), irregular bleeding or no bleeding over time  
     – Warning signs: very heavy bleeding, severe headaches, shortness of breath, or swelling/calves pain (rare)  

   Short-acting options that need action weekly or monthly  
   • Contraceptive patch (weekly) – 93 % typical, 99 % perfect  
   • Vaginal ring (monthly) – 93 % typical, 99 % perfect  

3. Side effects and health checks  
   Most side effects—whether with pills, injectables, implants or IUDs—are not dangerous and often settle after a few months.  Seek care immediately if you notice:  
   • Severe abdominal or chest pain, sudden shortness of breath  
   • Severe headaches with vision changes  
   • Very heavy vaginal bleeding (soaking > 2 pads per hour for several hours)  
   • Fainting, severe fever, or pus at an insertion site  

4. Accessing services in Rwanda  
   • All family-planning methods, counseling, and emergency contraception are available free or at low cost in public facilities and many community health posts.  
   • You do not need partner or parental consent, even if you are an adolescent or unmarried.  
   • You have the right to respectful, confidential, and non-judgmental care.  

5. Next steps you might consider  
   • Reflect on which method fits best with your lifestyle and preferences—daily routine, how often you want to think about contraception, menstrual changes you can accept, comfort with procedures, and desired timing of future pregnancy.  
   • When you are ready, visit the nearest health center or trusted provider.  You can ask to see and hold the various devices, confirm medical eligibility, and have all your questions answered before choosing.  
   • Bring your partner or a friend if that feels supportive, but the decision is yours.  

If at any point you feel unsure or experience the warning signs mentioned above, please seek professional medical care promptly.

must_include: Validates that forgetting pills is common
Explores reasons for forgetting (barriers)
Suggests practical adherence strategies (alarms, routine)
Offers long-acting alternatives that don't require daily action
Supports client choice
must_avoid: Only suggesting behavioral changes without mentioning method switch

responses.scenario: Can you just tell me what to use? I don't know enough to decide.
responses.ground_truth: I understand there are a lot of options and it can feel overwhelming. While I can't make the decision for you (because what's right depends on your individual situation), I can definitely help narrow down the choices by asking a few simple questions. Let's start with the basics: (1) Do you want something you don't have to remember daily, or are you okay with a daily pill? (2) Do you have any concerns about using hormones? (3) How important is it that you absolutely not get pregnant right now? Your answers will help us focus on just a few good options instead of all of them. Does that sound okay?
responses.model_response:
I understand that choosing a family-planning method can feel overwhelming. Instead of telling you what to use, I’ll guide you—step-by-step—so you can pick the method that best fits your life, health, and preferences. Everything below follows the 2022 WHO Family Planning Handbook, WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC), the Balanced Counseling Strategy (BCS+), and Rwanda’s national policy.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Let’s Clarify YOUR Needs (you can answer any you’re comfortable with)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• How soon (if at all) would you like to become pregnant in the future—within 1 year, after 2–3 years, 5 years, or never?  
• Would you prefer something you can forget about for months or years, or something you control each time you have sex?  
• Do you have any health conditions (e.g., high blood pressure, migraines with aura, diabetes, HIV, current breast cancer, etc.)?  
• Are you breastfeeding a baby under 6 months?  
• Would your partner’s cooperation matter (e.g., for condoms, withdrawal, fertility-awareness methods)?  
• How important is discretion (a method no one else can see)?  
• Are you comfortable with minor procedures (insertion/removal) if they give you long-term protection?  
• Do monthly visits for refills/injections work for you, or is travel/time off difficult?  
• Do you also need protection from HIV or other sexually transmitted infections (STIs)?

Your answers will narrow choices and reveal any medical conditions that might make a method unsafe (WHO MEC category 3 or 4) or require extra follow-up (category 2).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Methods Ranked by Effectiveness (Typical Use)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
(Perfect-use rates are even higher; bold numbers are pregnancies per 100 women in the first year of use.)

TIER 1 – Highest effectiveness  
• Hormonal implants (e.g., Implanon/Nexplanon, Jadelle): 0.1–0.4 pregnancies (99.6–99.9 % effective)  
• Copper IUD (non-hormonal): 0.8 pregnancies (99.2 %)  
• Levonorgestrel (LNG) hormonal IUD (Mirena, etc.): 0.2 pregnancies (99.8 %)  
• Female sterilization (permanent): 0.5 pregnancies (99.5 %)  
• Vasectomy (male sterilization): 0.15 pregnancies (99.85 %)

TIER 2 – High effectiveness if used correctly  
• Injectables (DMPA 3-monthly or NET-EN 2-monthly): 4 pregnancies (96 %)  
• Combined oral contraceptive pills: 7 pregnancies (93 %)  
• Progestin-only pills: 7 pregnancies (93 %)  
• Combined hormonal patch or vaginal ring (where available): 7 pregnancies (93 %)

TIER 3 – Moderate effectiveness  
• Male condoms: 13 pregnancies (87 %)—also protect against STIs/HIV  
• Female condoms: 21 pregnancies (79 %)—protect against STIs/HIV  
• Diaphragm with spermicide: 17 pregnancies (83 %)

TIER 4 – Lower effectiveness, user-dependent  
• Fertility-awareness-based methods (e.g., Standard Days, TwoDay, Symptothermal): 12–24 pregnancies (76–88 %)  
• Withdrawal: 20 pregnancies (80 %)  
• Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM): 2 pregnancies (98 %)—but only valid if baby < 6 months, exclusive breastfeeding, and menses not returned.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3. Safety Screening Highlights (WHO MEC)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Most healthy women can safely use any method (MEC 1). Important exceptions:  
• Combined estrogen methods (pills, patch, ring) are MEC 3/4 if you have: breastfeeding < 6 weeks postpartum, BP ≥160/100 mmHg, migraine with aura, certain clotting disorders, smoking ≥15 cigarettes/day and age ≥35, current breast cancer, etc.  
• Progestin-only methods (implants, injectable, POPs, LNG-IUD) are generally MEC 1 or 2 for most conditions, but current breast cancer is MEC 4.  
• Copper IUD is MEC 4 if you have current pelvic infection or unexplained vaginal bleeding, and MEC 3 if you have high risk of STIs or severe anemia.  
If any of these might apply, please mention them so a provider can confirm eligibility.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4. Key Features, Side Effects, & When to Seek Care
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Below is a concise overview of the most popular methods in Rwanda. Ask if you want details on any other option.

A. Hormonal Implant (3-5 years)  
• Small rod in upper arm; quick outpatient procedure.  
• Side effects: irregular or absent bleeding (common and not harmful), mild headaches, breast tenderness.  
• Warning signs: Very rare arm infection, severe pain, pregnancy symptoms.  
• Removal anytime. Fertility returns quickly.

B. Copper IUD (10+ years)  
• Non-hormonal, inserted in uterus.  
• Side effects: heavier, longer periods in first months, cramps.  
• Warning signs (PAINS): Period late, Abnormal pain, Infection exposure, Not feeling well (fever/chills), Strings missing—seek care.

C. Hormonal LNG-IUD (5–7 years)  
• Lighter periods, some spotting first 3–6 months.  
• Similar warning signs to copper IUD.

D. 3-Monthly Injectable (DMPA)  
• Get an injection every 12 weeks.  
• Side effects: irregular bleeding or no menses, slight weight gain, delayed return of fertility (≈4–10 months after last shot).  
• Warning signs: severe headaches, heavy bleeding, pus/redness at injection site.

E. Combined Oral Pills  
• Daily pill at same time.  
• Side effects: mild nausea, breast tenderness, light spotting first cycles.  
• Danger signs (ACHES): Abdominal pain, Chest pain, Headache severe, Eye/vision change, Severe leg pain—seek care immediately.

F. Male Condoms  
• Single use; protect against STIs/HIV.  
• Side effects: none except rare latex allergy.  
• Seek care for possible STI if you notice sores, discharge, or pain.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5. Cost & Access in Rwanda
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Public health facilities and accredited community health workers provide most methods free or at minimal cost.  
• Adolescents and unmarried clients have the same right to services; parental or partner consent is NOT required.  
• Confidentiality is respected.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6. Making Your Decision
--------------------------------------------------------------------
To help you choose, consider:

1. How important is highest possible effectiveness?  
2. Do you want a method you can stop without a clinic visit?  
3. Are hormonal side effects acceptable or would you prefer non-hormonal?  
4. Do you also need STI/HIV protection (condoms can be added to any method)?  
5. How soon do you plan another pregnancy?

If you let me know your priorities and any health issues, I can narrow the options further using WHO MEC and explain the short list in more depth.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
7. Next Steps
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Write down any questions or concerns.  
• Visit your nearest health center or community health worker—they will confirm you are medically eligible (MEC screening), provide the method, and give you detailed instructions.  
• Return or call if you experience danger signs, want to switch methods, or need more supplies.

You are in control of this decision, and it’s completely okay to try a method and later change it. Let me know what matters most to you, and we’ll go from there.

must_include: Acknowledges feeling overwhelmed is normal
Offers to narrow down options together (collaborative)
Asks a few key questions to guide selection
Empowers client while providing structure
Maintains client autonomy
must_avoid: Making the decision for the client

non_compliant_indicators: Makes decision for client without input

responses.scenario: I think my partner is trying to get me pregnant without my consent. Can birth control help?
responses.ground_truth: I'm really glad you felt comfortable sharing this with me. What you're describing is called reproductive coercion, and it's a form of abuse. Your safety and autonomy are important. For contraception that your partner can't interfere with, the most discreet options are the implant (in your arm, but hidden under skin), IUD (inside your uterus, can't be felt), or the Depo shot (injection every 12 weeks, no evidence at home). Pills, patches, and rings can be found or tampered with. Beyond contraception, I'm concerned about your safety. Are you in a safe situation right now? I can provide information about local domestic violence resources if that would be helpful. You deserve support and safety.
responses.model_response:
I’m sorry you are experiencing this situation. Many people face pressure or interference with their reproductive choices, and there are contraceptive methods that can give you more control and privacy. Let’s review them so you can decide what feels safest and most acceptable to you. Everything below is based on the 2022 WHO Family Planning Handbook, the WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC), the Balanced Counseling Strategy+, and—if you are in Rwanda—the 2021 National Family Planning Policy.  

-------------------------------------------------
1. Long-acting, highly effective methods that can be used without a partner’s knowledge or involvement  
-------------------------------------------------

A. Subdermal Implant  
• What it is: 1–2 small plastic rods placed under the skin of the upper arm.  
• Effectiveness:  
  – Typical use: >99% (about 0.1–0.4 pregnancies per 100 users in the first year).  
  – Perfect use: >99%.  
• How private? Completely hidden under the skin; only a health-care provider can feel it on close examination. No supplies are kept at home.  
• Duration: 3–5 years (depending on brand) but removable any time. Fertility returns quickly after removal.  
• Side-effects: Irregular bleeding or spotting (most common), light or no bleeding, headaches, mood changes, acne. These usually lessen after the first few months.  
• Warning signs/seek care: Very severe lower-abdominal pain (could indicate ovarian cyst or ectopic pregnancy—rare); signs of infection at insertion site (redness, pus, fever); pregnancy signs.  
• WHO MEC: Category 1 for most women. Certain conditions (e.g., current breast cancer = Cat 4) require other options, so disclose any serious illness to the provider.  
• Follow-up: Return any time you wish to remove, if you have side-effects you cannot manage, or if you suspect pregnancy.

B. Copper-bearing IUD (Cu-IUD)  
• What it is: A small T-shaped device placed in the uterus.  
• Effectiveness:  
  – Typical use: >99% (0.6–0.8 pregnancies per 100 users in the first year).  
  – Perfect use: >99%.  
• How private? Strings usually rest inside the vagina; a partner generally cannot feel them during sex. Provider can trim strings very short if you are worried about detection.  
• Duration: 10–12 years (depending on brand) but removable any time. Fertility returns immediately.  
• Side-effects: Heavier or more painful periods for some users, especially in the first 3–6 months.  
• Warning signs/seek care: Severe lower-abdominal pain, heavy bleeding, foul discharge, missed period with pregnancy symptoms.  
• WHO MEC: Category 1 for most women who do not have current pelvic infection, unexplained vaginal bleeding, or certain cancers.  
• Extra benefit: Can also be used as emergency contraception if inserted within 5 days of unprotected sex.

C. Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD (LNG-IUD)  
• What it is: A hormonal T-shaped device placed in the uterus.  
• Effectiveness: >99% (0.1–0.3 pregnancies per 100 users in the first year).  
• Duration: 5–8 years (brand-specific).  
• Privacy, side-effects, warning signs: Similar to Cu-IUD, but periods usually become lighter or stop—many women like this.  
• WHO MEC: Category 1 for most, Cat 4 for current breast cancer.

D. Injectable contraceptives  
1. DMPA (3-month) or 2. NET-EN (2-month)  
• Effectiveness:  
  – Typical use: ~94 % (6 pregnancies per 100 users in the first year).  
  – Perfect use: >99%.  
• Privacy: Single injection in the arm/buttock every 8–12 weeks. No visible marks after a day or two; nothing to store at home.  
• Side-effects: Irregular bleeding or no bleeding, weight gain, delayed return to fertility (average 4–10 months after last injection), headaches.  
• Warning signs: Very heavy bleeding, migraine with aura, severe lower-abdominal pain, pregnancy signs.  
• WHO MEC: Category 1 for most. Current breast cancer = Cat 4. Severe hypertension or unexplained vaginal bleeding = Cat 3.  
• Follow-up: Return for next injection on time; can switch or stop any time.

-------------------------------------------------
2. User-controlled methods that are somewhat easier for a partner to notice  
-------------------------------------------------

These may still be useful if you feel safe keeping supplies:  

• Oral contraceptive pills (combined or progestin-only) – 93 % typical, >99 % perfect. Must take daily and keep packets.  
• Emergency contraceptive pills (ECPs: levonorgestrel 1.5 mg up to 120 h; or ulipristal 30 mg up to 120 h). Can keep a dose on hand in case of condom tampering or forced sex. Typical effectiveness: 58–95 % depending on timing; earlier is better.  
• Female condoms or diaphragms – can be inserted yourself, but partner may notice.  
• Fertility awareness methods or withdrawal – less reliable and often need partner cooperation, so usually not recommended in situations of coercion.  
• Male condoms – highly effective with perfect use (98 %), but typical use is ~87 % and partner must cooperate.

-------------------------------------------------
3. Other considerations
-------------------------------------------------

• Dual protection against STIs/HIV: If you are at risk, the safest approach is a hidden method (e.g., implant) plus a condom whenever possible.  
• Pregnancy testing and emergency contraception: Keep a pregnancy test and ECPs where your partner will not find them if you think sabotage occurs.  
• Future fertility: All WHO-recommended modern methods are reversible except sterilization.

-------------------------------------------------
4. Your safety and well-being
-------------------------------------------------

Reproductive coercion is a form of intimate partner violence.  
• If you ever feel unsafe, consider reaching out to a trusted friend, family member, or a gender-based-violence hotline.  
• In Rwanda, toll-free hotlines include 3512 (Isange One-Stop Center) and 116 (Child/GBV helpline).  
• Health-care providers are trained to give confidential support; you can ask to speak privately without your partner present.  
• You have the legal right in Rwanda to obtain contraception without a partner’s or parent’s consent, and services at public facilities are free or very low-cost.

-------------------------------------------------
5. Next steps
-------------------------------------------------

1. Think about which features matter most to you: length of protection, ability to keep it hidden, frequency of visits, possible side-effects.  
2. Visit a clinic or pharmacy when you can go alone or with someone you trust. Let the provider know you are concerned about privacy so they can help choose and place a method discreetly.  
3. If you have any medical conditions (e.g., high blood pressure, diabetes, migraines, breast issues, recent childbirth, etc.), tell the provider so they can apply the WHO MEC and be sure the method is safe for you.  
4. Schedule follow-up or removal only when you feel it is safe. Remember—you can switch methods anytime.

-------------------------------------------------
6. Warning signs—seek care immediately if you experience:
-------------------------------------------------
• Sudden severe abdominal pain or fainting (possible ectopic pregnancy).  
• Heavy vaginal bleeding soaking >2 pads/hour for 2 consecutive hours.  
• Fever or foul discharge after an insertion or injection.  
• Severe headaches with vision changes (especially if using hormonal methods).  
• Any suspected pregnancy while on contraception.

-------------------------------------------------
I hope this information helps you feel more in control of your reproductive health. You deserve to make these decisions freely and safely. If anything is unclear or you’d like to discuss more details, please let me know.

must_include: Takes concern seriously, non-judgmental
Discusses covert methods partner can't detect/interfere with
Mentions IUD, implant, Depo shot as hidden options
Provides safety planning support
Offers resources or referral for domestic violence support
must_avoid: Only discussing contraception without addressing safety

responses.scenario: I don't want my parents to know I'm on birth control. What are my options?
responses.ground_truth: Your privacy is important. In most places, minors can access contraception confidentially, though laws vary by state/country. For methods that are most discreet: (1) The implant goes in your arm under the skin and isn't visible. (2) An IUD is inside your uterus and can't be seen or felt. (3) The Depo shot is given every 12 weeks with no supplies at home. Pills, patches, and rings are harder to keep private. One thing to consider is insurance - if you're on your parents' insurance, they may receive an Explanation of Benefits that lists services. Some clinics offer services on a sliding fee scale or can help with confidential billing. Would you like information about confidential clinics in your area?
responses.model_response:
I hear that you would like reliable pregnancy prevention but do not want your parents to know. Let’s go through your choices in a confidential, non-judgmental way so you can decide what works best for you. Everything below is based on the 2022 WHO Family Planning Handbook, WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC), the Balanced Counseling Strategy (BCS+) and, in case you are in Rwanda, the 2021 National FP Policy (which allows adolescents to obtain family-planning services without parental consent and at low or no cost in public facilities).

1. How private can services be?
• Health-care workers are required to keep your visit confidential. You may attend alone or with someone you trust.  
• In Rwanda, you can receive any modern contraceptive method (including implants and IUDs) without showing an ID, without a guardian, and free or at minimal cost in public facilities.  
• You can ask the provider to note only the minimum information in your file and to avoid calling or texting you if you prefer.

2. Discreet methods you control
Below are methods that leave little or no evidence at home once provided. All are WHO MEC category 1 for healthy adolescents.

A. Hormonal implant (e.g. Jadelle, Implanon)
   • What it is: 1–2 small rods placed under the skin of the upper arm; lasts 3–5 years.  
   • Effectiveness: <1 pregnancy per 100 users in the first year (typical and perfect use ≃ 0.1%).  
   • Privacy: Totally hidden; only a small bump that you can feel. No supplies to store.  
   • Common side-effects: Irregular bleeding or no periods, mild headache, breast tenderness.  
   • Warning signs (rare): Heavy bleeding, severe abdominal pain, pus/redness at insertion site—seek care.  
   • Removal: Can be taken out at any time if you change your mind; fertility returns quickly.

B. Intrauterine device (IUD)
   1. Copper T 380A (non-hormonal, 10+ years)  
   2. LNG-IUS (hormonal, 5 years)  
   • Effectiveness: 0.8% (Copper) or 0.2% (LNG-IUS) typical use.  
   • Privacy: Nothing to see externally; only you and the provider know.  
   • Side-effects: Copper—heavier periods in first months; LNG-IUS—lighter or no periods.  
   • Warning signs: Pelvic pain, fever, foul discharge, missed period with pregnancy symptoms—seek care.  
   • Needs pelvic insertion by a trained provider; you can ask for a female provider if that is more comfortable.

C. Injectable contraceptive (e.g. Depo-Provera, Sayana Press)
   • Given every 3 months (DMPA) or every 2 months (NET-EN).  
   • Effectiveness: Typical use ≈ 4 pregnancies/100 women per year; correct-time injections ≈ 0.2%.  
   • Privacy: No supplies at home; a brief clinic visit or self-injection option (Sayana Press) that you can keep privately.  
   • Side-effects: Irregular bleeding or no periods, weight change, delayed return of fertility (4–10 months on average).  
   • Warning signs: Severe headaches, heavy bleeding, swelling/redness where injected—seek care.

D. Progestin-only pills (POPs) or combined oral pills (COCs)
   • Taken daily at the same time.  
   • Effectiveness: Typical use 7 pregnancies/100 women per year; perfect use ≈ 0.3%.  
   • Privacy: Packets may be found; you decide if that is acceptable.  
   • Side-effects: Nausea (often improves), spotting, breast tenderness.  
   • Warning signs: Severe chest pain, migraines with aura, leg swelling (mostly COCs).  
   • If living with parents, think about hiding/storing the packet and silent phone reminders.

E. Emergency contraception (EC)
   • 1.5 mg levonorgestrel pill(s) within 120 hours of unprotected sex; sooner is better.  
   • Prevents 52–95 % of expected pregnancies depending on timing.  
   • Does not affect ongoing fertility; can be used more than once, but is not a regular method.  
   • Available over the counter in many countries; keep receipt and packaging private if needed.

F. Condoms (male or female)
   • Effectiveness: Male—typical 13%, perfect 2%; Female—typical 21%, perfect 5%.  
   • Added benefit of STI/HIV prevention.  
   • Packets are visible, but you can carry a few discreetly.  
   • Side-effects: None, unless latex allergy (latex-free versions exist).  

3. How to choose?
• Think about what matters most: privacy, how often you want to think about contraception, menstrual changes, and protection from STIs/HIV.  
• Many people combine methods (e.g., implant + condom) for extra protection and STI prevention.  
• You have the right to start, switch, or stop any method at any time.

4. Practical tips for keeping contraceptive use private
• Schedule clinic visits during school breaks or times your parents expect you to be elsewhere.  
• Ask the clinic not to stamp your health booklet with the method name, or to write acronyms only.  
• For injectables or implants, wear clothing that covers the upper arm on the day of insertion.  
• Store pills or condoms in a private pouch, phone case, or trusted friend’s place if needed.  
• Use a phone app with a neutral icon or set silent alarms for reminders.  

5. When to return to the clinic or seek care urgently
• Any severe abdominal or pelvic pain, heavy or prolonged bleeding, fever with pelvic pain, or if you suspect pregnancy.  
• For hormonal methods: sudden severe headache, chest pain, trouble breathing, leg pain.  
• If a condom breaks, consider EC within 5 days.

6. Next steps
If you feel ready, visit a nearby health center, youth corner, pharmacy, or community health worker. You can simply say you want family-planning services; no one should require your parents’ approval. The provider will review your medical history to confirm eligibility (MEC category) and will help you start the method you choose.

Remember, you are in control of your reproductive health. If you have further questions or concerns, feel free to ask or speak confidentially with a trained health-care provider.

must_include: Explains confidentiality rights (age-dependent)
Discusses discreet methods (implant, IUD, shot)
Addresses insurance/billing privacy concerns
Provides information about accessing care confidentially
Non-judgmental support
must_avoid: Encouraging client to tell parents without consent

responses.scenario: I heard IUDs can make you infertile. Is that true?
responses.ground_truth: No, that's a common myth but it's not true. IUDs do not cause infertility. Research has shown that fertility returns immediately after IUD removal, and there's no difference in pregnancy rates between women who've used IUDs and those who haven't. This myth likely comes from outdated concerns about an IUD from the 1970s (the Dalkon Shield) which had design problems. Modern IUDs are very safe and don't affect your future fertility at all. Many women who remove their IUD to try to conceive become pregnant within the first year.
responses.model_response:
I’m glad you asked—there are many myths about IUDs (intra-uterine devices) and infertility. Here is what the evidence from the 2022 WHO Family Planning Handbook and Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC) tells us.  

1. Do IUDs cause infertility?  
• No. Large, well-designed studies have found no link between modern IUD use (either copper-bearing or hormonal/levonorgestrel) and future infertility.  
• Fertility returns quickly after removal. In most studies, about 80 – 90 % of women who want to become pregnant conceive within 12 months of IUD removal—similar to women who never used an IUD.

2. Where did the myth come from?  
• Decades ago, an older IUD model (the Dalkon Shield, no longer on the market) was associated with pelvic infections and infertility. Today’s IUDs are designed differently and are safe.  
• Any untreated sexually transmitted infection (STI) can lead to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) and, rarely, infertility—whether or not a woman uses an IUD. To minimise this risk, providers screen for STI symptoms before inserting the IUD and use clean/aseptic technique.

3. How effective are IUDs?  
Typical-use pregnancy rates (first year of use):  
• Copper-bearing IUD: about 8 pregnancies per 1,000 women (0.8 %).  
• Levonorgestrel (hormonal) IUD: about 1 pregnancy per 1,000 women (0.1 %).  
Perfect-use rates are slightly lower.

4. Who can use an IUD? (WHO MEC)  
• Category 1 (no restriction) or 2 (advantages generally outweigh risks) for most women, including adolescents and women who have not yet had a child.  
• Your provider will ask about certain conditions (e.g., current pelvic infection, certain cancers, unexplained vaginal bleeding) that may place you in Category 3 or 4 (not usually recommended).

5. Common side-effects (not harmful but worth knowing)  
Copper IUD:  
• Heavier or longer periods, more cramps—often improve after the first few months.  
Hormonal (LNG) IUD:  
• Lighter periods, spotting, or no bleeding at all after several months.  
Most side-effects lessen with time; if they bother you, seek advice rather than simply discontinuing.

6. Warning signs—when to seek care (remember the acronym “PAINS”)  
P—Period late (possible pregnancy) or very irregular after being regular  
A—Abdominal pain or pain with intercourse  
I—Infection signs: unusual vaginal discharge, fever, chills  
N—Not feeling well, strong cramping, or severe fatigue  
S—Strings missing, shorter, or longer than before (may indicate expulsion)  
If any of these occur, visit a health facility promptly.

7. Cost and access in Rwanda  
• IUD services are free or low-cost in public facilities.  
• Adolescents and unmarried women can obtain an IUD without parental or partner consent, and services should be provided in a confidential, respectful manner.

8. Your next steps  
• If you are interested in an IUD, a trained provider will review your medical history, examine you as needed, and insert the device during a brief visit.  
• If an IUD isn’t your preference, many other highly effective methods are available. You have the right to choose what feels best for you.

Feel free to ask more questions or discuss any concerns—your decision will be respected, and comprehensive information is always available.

must_include: Explicitly debunks the myth (IUDs do NOT cause infertility)
Cites evidence or research
Explains that fertility returns immediately after removal
Provides reassurance with facts

who_guideline.fact: IUDs do not cause infertility; fertility returns immediately upon removal
who_guideline.evidence: Multiple studies show no difference in fertility between IUD users and non-users

responses.scenario: I've been on the pill for 3 years. Do I need to take a break from it?
responses.ground_truth: No, you don't need to take a break from the pill. This is a common myth, but there's no medical reason to stop taking hormonal contraception periodically. Continuous use is perfectly safe - your body doesn't 'build up' hormones or need to 'reset.' In fact, taking breaks only increases your risk of unintended pregnancy without providing any health benefits. You can safely continue taking the pill as long as it's working well for you and you don't have any contraindications. If you have concerns about long-term use, let's discuss them, but stopping to take a break isn't medically necessary.
responses.model_response:
