responses.scenario: I'm HIV positive and on ARVs. Which contraceptive methods are safe for me in Rwanda?
responses.ground_truth: Most contraceptive methods are safe for women living with HIV on ART. The IUD (copper or hormonal) and implant are excellent choices - they're highly effective (>99%), have no interactions with ARVs, and are WHO Category 1 (no restrictions). However, some ARVs (especially ritonavir-boosted protease inhibitors) can reduce the effectiveness of pills, patch, and ring. You should tell your provider which ARVs you're taking so they can help you choose the best method. Rwanda's integrated FP-HIV services make this easy. Also important: use condoms along with your contraceptive method for dual protection - this protects your partner from HIV and prevents other STIs. You have full access to all contraceptive options.
responses.model_response:
Thank you for sharing this information.  According to the 2022 WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC) and Rwanda’s 2021 National Family Planning Policy, almost every family-planning method can be used safely by a woman who is HIV-positive and taking antiretroviral therapy (ART), provided she has no other medical conditions.  
Below you will find:

1. WHO safety category for each method when a woman is HIV-positive and clinically stable on ART  
 •  Category 1 = no restriction •  Category 2 = advantages generally outweigh any theoretical or proven risk  
2. Typical-use and perfect-use effectiveness  
3. Key advantages, possible side-effects, drug-interaction issues, and when to seek care  
4. Notes on access in Rwanda and on dual protection

Feel free to read only the methods that interest you, and you can decide which (if any) you would like to discuss further with a health-care provider.

────────────────────────────────
HIGHLY EFFECTIVE, LONG-ACTING REVERSIBLE METHODS
────────────────────────────────
Copper IUD (Cu-T, TCu-380A, etc.)  
• WHO MEC: Category 2 if you are clinically well on ART; Category 3 if you have AIDS symptoms not yet controlled.  
• Effectiveness: Typical 0.8 pregnancies/100 women in first year; perfect 0.6.  
• Advantages: Works 10–12 years; immediately reversible; no hormones—no interaction with ARVs.  
• Possible side-effects: Heavier/longer periods or more cramps in first months.  
• Warning signs (go to facility): Very heavy bleeding, severe lower-abdominal pain, foul-smelling discharge, fever, missed strings.  

Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD (LNG-IUD, e.g. Mirena)  
• WHO MEC: Category 2 if clinically well; Category 3 if AIDS not controlled.  
• Effectiveness: Typical & perfect ≈ 0.2/100.  
• Advantages: Lighter periods, may stop menstruation; 5+ years of protection.  
• Possible side-effects: Spotting in first 3–6 months, then lighter or no menses.  
• Same warning signs as Cu-IUD.  

Implants (2-rod LNG or 1-rod ENG)  
• WHO MEC: Category 2 (because some ARVs can lower hormone levels).  
• Effectiveness: Typical & perfect ≈ 0.1/100, but may be slightly lower (~1/100) if using efavirenz-containing ART.  
• Advantages: 3–5 years, very discreet.  
• Drug interaction note: Efavirenz and some protease inhibitors can reduce effectiveness. WHO recommends using condoms as well (dual protection) or choosing DMPA or an IUD if you prefer a single highly effective method.  
• Side-effects: Irregular bleeding or no bleeding; usually improve over time.  
• Warning signs: Very heavy bleeding, severe abdominal pain, infection at insertion site.

────────────────────────────────
INJECTABLES
────────────────────────────────
DMPA (Depo-Provera IM or Sayana Press SC)  
• WHO MEC: Category 1 (no restriction).  
• Effectiveness: Typical 4/100; perfect 0.2/100.  
• Advantages: One injection every 3 months; unaffected by ARVs.  
• Side-effects: Irregular or no periods, weight change, delayed return to fertility (≈ 3–6 months after last injection), possible slight loss of bone density (reversible).  
• Warning signs: Very heavy bleeding, severe headaches, injection-site infection.  

NET-EN (2-month injectable)  
• Same profile as DMPA; Category 1.

────────────────────────────────
COMBINED HORMONAL METHODS (oestrogen + progestin)
────────────────────────────────
Combined oral pills (COCs), combined patch, combined vaginal ring  
• WHO MEC: Category 2 (because some ARVs can lower hormone levels).  
• Effectiveness (COCs): Typical 7/100; perfect 0.3/100. Patch & ring are similar.  
• Drug interaction note: Efavirenz or ritonavir can reduce hormone levels; use condoms or choose a non-interacting method.  
• Side-effects: Nausea, breast tenderness, spotting, slight blood-pressure rise (usually mild and often resolve).  
• Warning signs (ACHES): Abdominal pain, Chest pain, severe Headaches, Eye problems, Severe leg pain—seek care immediately.

────────────────────────────────
PROGESTIN-ONLY PILLS (POPs, “mini-pills”)
────────────────────────────────
• WHO MEC: Category 2 (possible reduced levels with some ARVs).  
• Effectiveness: Typical 7/100; perfect 0.3/100. Must take at same time daily.  
• Side-effects/Warning signs: Similar to implants but milder; seek care for very heavy/continuous bleeding.

────────────────────────────────
BARRIER & TRADITIONAL METHODS
────────────────────────────────
Male condoms (latex or polyurethane)  
• WHO MEC: Category 1.  
• Effectiveness: Typical 13/100; perfect 2/100.  
• Key point: Only method that also prevents HIV/STI transmission to partners—strongly recommended in addition to another method (“dual protection”).  

Female/internal condoms  
• Typical 21/100; perfect 5/100.  

Diaphragm/Cervical cap  
• WHO MEC: Category 1.  
• Effectiveness: Typical 17/100; perfect 6/100.  
• Note: Does NOT protect against HIV; must always be used with condoms for dual protection.  

Fertility-awareness methods (Standard Days, TwoDay, BBT, etc.)  
• WHO MEC: Category 1.  
• Effectiveness: Typical 15/100; perfect 3/100.  
• Need for partner cooperation; no interaction with ARVs.

Withdrawal, Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM), abstinence  
• No medical restrictions, but higher failure rates (except LAM in first 6 months postpartum, typical 2/100).

────────────────────────────────
PERMANENT METHODS
────────────────────────────────
Female sterilization (tubal ligation) | Male sterilization (vasectomy)  
• WHO MEC: Category 1.  
• Effectiveness: <1/100.  
• Permanent—only choose if you are sure you do not want any more children.  
• No interaction with ARVs.

────────────────────────────────
EMERGENCY CONTRACEPTION
────────────────────────────────
• Copper IUD within 5 days: Category 2, most effective (<0.1% failure).  
• Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg pills: Category 1, but efavirenz may lower levels—take double dose (3 mg) if using efavirenz-based ART (WHO recommendation).  
• Ulipristal acetate: Limited data with ARVs—consult provider.

────────────────────────────────
WHEN TO SEEK CARE URGENTLY
────────────────────────────────
• Severe abdominal or pelvic pain  
• Very heavy or prolonged bleeding  
• Signs of infection (fever, foul discharge)  
• Severe headaches, vision changes, chest pain, leg swelling (if on combined hormones)  
• Any suspected pregnancy while using a method  

────────────────────────────────
ACCESS & COST IN RWANDA
────────────────────────────────
• All modern methods (pills, injectables, implants, IUDs, condoms, sterilization) are available free or at low cost in public health centres and through community health workers.  
• You do NOT need partner or parental consent, even for long-acting methods.  
• Services are confidential and non-discriminatory. Feel free to ask for a female provider or bring a support person if you prefer.  

────────────────────────────────
KEY TAKE-AWAYS
────────────────────────────────
1. Being HIV-positive and on ART does NOT exclude you from any method, but some hormonal methods (pills, patch, ring, implants) can be a little less effective with certain ART drugs.  
2. If you want a method completely unaffected by ART, consider an IUD (copper or LNG) or DMPA injectable, plus condoms for STI protection.  
3. Whatever method you choose, using condoms as well (“dual protection”) is strongly recommended to protect your partner(s) and to prevent other STIs.  
4. You have the right to full information and free choice. A nurse, midwife, or doctor can help you decide what fits your needs and can check for any additional health issues.  

Would you like more details on any specific method, or help thinking through what might fit best with your lifestyle and ART regimen?

responses.scenario: Ndashaka gukoresha igipimo. Ni iki nakoresha? (I want to use contraception. What can I use?)
responses.ground_truth: Murakoze kubaza! (Thank you for asking!) Hari uburyo bwinshi bwo kwirinda inda (There are many ways to prevent pregnancy): imiti (pills), inkoni (implant), IUD, inshinge (injection/Depo), na condom. Mbere yo gutanga inama, ndashaka kubaza: Ufite indwara runaka? Ushaka uburyo buhora igihe kirekire cyangwa bwihuta? (Before advising, I want to ask: Do you have any health conditions? Do you want a long-term method or short-term?) Dufatanye turebe icyiza kuri wewe. (Let's work together to see what's best for you.) Urashobora kubaza mu Kinyarwanda cyangwa Icyongereza - byombi nibyo. (You can ask in Kinyarwanda or English - both are fine.)
responses.model_response:
Muraho neza! Nishimiye ko ushaka kumenya uburyo bwo kuboneza urubyaro (family planning). Kugira ngo dufatanye guhitamo neza, ndifuza kubanza kukubaza bimwe mu bibazo bituma tumenya uburyo bujyanye n’imibereho yawe n’ubuzima bwawe. Niba ubishoboye, wakansubiza:

1. Ufite imyaka ingahe? (Abangavu bemerewe serivisi nta burenganzira bwa ababyeyi basabwa.)
2. Ufite abana? Urifuza kongera kuvuka ry’abana ryari? 
3. Uronsa cyangwa uteganya konsa? Umwana wawe ari munsi y’amezi 6/6-12/12+?
4. Ufite ubundi burwayi cyangwa umwivuruguto (nka diyabete, umuvuduko w’amaraso, indwara z’umutima, gufata imiti ya TB/VIH, etc.)?
5. Ese urifuza uburyo bumara igihe kirekire (imyaka), igihe gito (amezi/ibyumweru), uburyo bwo gukoreshwa mbere y’imibonano, cyangwa ushobora no kuba ushaka kudasama burundu (sterilisation)?
6. Ese wifuza n’ubwirinzi ku ndwara zandurira mu mibonano mpuzabitsina?
7. Ese ufite cyangwa ushobora kubonera hafi serivisi z’ubuzima aho utuye (postes de santé, centre de santé, ibitaro)?

Niba utarabitekerezaho cyangwa utifuza gusubiza byose hano, ntakibazo—ushobora kumpa amakuru make, nanone nyuma ukaganira n’umukozi w’ishami ry’ubuzima hafi yawe. 

Mbere y’uko duhitamo, reka nguhe incamake y’amatsinda y’uburyo bwo kuboneza urubyaro, uko bukora, n’uko bunoze (perfect use) bupfa kugenda ubugira (typical use). Iyi mibare ikomoka kuri WHO 2022:

UBURYO BUMARA IGIHE KIREKIRE BUDASABA KUBITEKEREZAHO KENSHI (Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptives, LARC)  
• Agakingirizo katera (Implant – Implanon/Nexplanon, Jadelle, Levoplant)  
  – Inanirwa 0.1 % (perfect) / <1 % (typical) mu mwaka  
  – Gukora: gushyirwa munsi y’uruhu ku kuboko, kumara imyaka 3–5  
  – MEC 1 kuri benshi; biba MEC 3 cyangwa 4 mu ndwara nke zidasanzwe (nka kanseri y’inkondo y’umura ikomeye, etc.)  
  – Ibimenyetso bishobora kugaragara: imihango idasanzwe cyangwa ikarangira, kubyimba mu ntoki cyangwa aho baterera (**rimrare**), umutwe.  
• Udukingirizo tw’imbere mu mura (IUD)  
  – TCu380A (mubiri w’umbra) : inanirwa 0.6 % (perfect) / 0.8 % (typical)  
  – Hormonal LNG-IUS (Mirena/Liletta) : 0.1 % (perfect & typical)  
  – Gushyirwa mu gituba n’umuganga wabyigiye, kumara imyaka 5–10  
  – MEC 1 kuri benshi. Ntitwakora igihe ufite infection y’udukoko mu gitsina (PID) idakize cyangwa uri hafi by’ukwezi umwe ubyaye (post-partum <4 weeks).  
  – Ibishoboka: imihango myinshi (TCu) cyangwa mikeya (LNG-IUS), kuribwa mu kiziba cy’inda mu minsi ya mbere.  

UBURYO BUMARA IGIHE KIGUFI  
• Inshinge (Depo-Provera DMPA/ Sayana Press)  
  – Inanirwa 0.2 % (perfect) / 4 % (typical)  
  – Gutera buri mezi 3; MEC 1 kuri benshi, MEC 3-4 niba ufite umuvuduko ukabije, gutonekara k’umwuma (severe hypertension >160/100), cyangwa kanseri y’ibere.  
  – Ibishoboka: gusiba cyangwa kurushaho kugira imihango, gutakaza umubyimba w’amagufwa (ku bangavu: gusubira mu magufwa akomeye iyo uyihagaritse), kwiyongera ibiro ku bagore bamwe.  
• Ibirimo imisemburo binyobwa buri munsi (Combined oral pills cyangwa progestin-only pills)  
  – COCP: 0.3 % (perfect) / 7 % (typical). POC: 0.3 % / 7 %  
  – Ujya ufata buri munsi ku isaha imwe; MEC 4 niba uri konsa <6 weeks (COCP), ufite migraine ifite aura, umuvuduko w’amaraso ukabije, kanseri y’ibere, n’ibindi.  
  – Ibishoboka: kubabara amabere, isesemi, imihango icikagurika.  
• Patch cyangwa Vaginal Ring (ntibiraboneka henshi muri Rwanda)  
  – 0.3 % / 7 %  
• Ubwirinzi bwo mu kanwa bw’umunsi umwe (Emergency Contraception) – si bwo bwo kuboneza k’urubyaro rwa buri munsi ariko ni ingenzi igihe condo yapfumutse, wibagiwe pilule, cyangwa gusambanywa ku gahato.  
  – Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg cyangwa 0.75 mg×2: kugabanya ibyago byo gusama ku kigero cya 58–95 % bitewe n’igihe ufatiye (ni byiza <72h, bishobora kugera 120h).  
  – Cu-IUD nayo ni emergency contraception ifasha 99 % itangewe <5 iminsi.  

UBURYO BUBONEKA AKENSHI BUKENERA KUBITEKEREZAHO BURI GIHE  
• Agakingirizo k’abagabo  
  – 2 % (perfect) / 13 % (typical)  
  – Wongera ubwizingizi ku ndwara zandurira mu mibonano mpuzabitsina (STI/VIH).  
• Agakingirizo k’abagore  
  – 5 % / 21 %  
• Uburyo bwo kumenya iminsi fertile (Fertility Awareness)  
  – Kalendari (Standard Days): 5 % / 12 %  
  – Amatembabuzi (TwoDay, Billings), température, n’ubundi buryo: 1–5 % / 15–24 %  
• Gukuramo igitsina (withdrawal): 4 % (perfect) / 20 % (typical).  

UBURYO BURAMIRA (Permanent Methods)  
• Gufunga imiyoboro y’intanga ku bagabo (Vasectomy): 0.1–0.15 %.  
• Gufunga imiyoboro y’inda ku bagore (Tubal ligation): 0.5 %.  
Izi ni ndakuka (irreversible), ukaba ugomba kubanza kubitekerezaho neza.  

IBYO UJYA WIBUKA  
• Imbata y’ubuyobozi (WHO MEC): nta buryo bwihariye buhawe amenyo ku bakecuru cyangwa abangavu; buri gihe hagenzurwa kuko hari ibyiciro MEC 1 (nta kibazo), MEC 2 (inyungu iruta ingaruka), MEC 3 (ingaruka ziruta inyungu – bikwiye kugirwa inama) na MEC 4 (birabujijwe).  
• Mu Rwanda, serivisi nyinshi za FP zitangirwa ubuntu cyangwa ku kiguzi gito mu bigo nderabuzima. Abangavu n’abagore batashakanye bemerewe kuhabona serivisi kandi ibanga ribakirinda.  
• Side effects hafi ya zose ntizihungabanya ubuzima, ariko niba ubonye ibimenyetso bikurikira, jya kwa muganga:  
  – Kubabara ikirere cyangwa amaraso menshi cyane nyuma yo gushyirwa IUD  
  – Kuribwa mu gituza, umutwe ukabije udakira, kubyimba amaguru (CHC)  
  – Kugira umuriro, kubabara aho baterera implant cyangwa injection bikabije  
  – Kudasama cyangwa kugira ibimenyetso by’uburwayi bwa kanseri y’ibere.  

IBI BIHE UGOMBA KWITABIRA SERIVISI VUBA  
• Kubabara mu kiziba cy’inda cyangwa amaraso menshi nyuma yo gusuzuma IUD/implant  
• Gufata imiti ya rifampicin, anti-convulsants, antiretrovirals—bishobora kugabanya imikorere ya pilule cyangwa implanti  
• Kuba umenyeko atwite cyangwa ukeka ko utwite.  

GUFATA ICYEMEZO  
Ndifuza kumva icyo wifuza: ushaka ikimara igihe kirekire utiriwe wibuka buri munsi, cyangwa ushaka ikigufasha na STIs, cyangwa ushobora kuba wifuza icyo gufata mbere y’imibonano gusa.  
• Niba wifuza ikimara byinshi, implant cyangwa IUD ni uburyo bufite ikigero cyo kugoreka (failure) hasi cyane (<1 %).  
• Niba uri konsa umwana uri munsi y’amezi 6, ushobora gukoresha LAM (Lactational Amenorrhea Method) cyangwa inshinge DMPA/implant kuko MEC 1. Ibyo birimo estrogen (COC, Patch, Ring) ni MEC 4 mu mezi 6 ya mbere yo konsa.  
• Niba wifuza n’ubwirinzi ku ndwara zandurira mu mibonano, agakingirizo ni ngombwa, gashobora guhuzwa n’ubundi buryo.  

ESE WAMPA AMAKURU YISUMBAHO?  
Icyo gihe twagerageza guhata buri buryo ku rutonde rujyanye n’imibereho yawe (Balanced Counseling Strategy Step 2), tukarekamo izo utakwemerewe (Step 3), hanyuma ibikorwa byo guhitamo bigahera ku bisigaye (Step 4).  

Niba wifuza, wanyandikira ibindi bisobanuro cyangwa ukagana ikigo nderabuzima kiri hafi, aho bazakomeza kugusuzuma ubuzima (blood pressure, amateka y’imiryango, nibindi) banaguhe ubwawe igikorwa wahisemo.  

Ndahari niba hari ikindi ushaka kubaza!

Uses simple, accessible language
Asks about client's needs before recommending
Mentions multiple options in lay terms

responses.scenario: Can a Community Health Worker (Animatrice) give me contraception, or do I need to go to the health center?
responses.ground_truth: Community Health Workers (Animatrices) in Rwanda can provide you with birth control pills and condoms, and they can counsel you on all contraceptive methods. However, for the implant, IUD, or Depo-Provera injection, you'll need to visit a health center or hospital where trained providers can insert or administer these methods. CHWs can help you understand your options and give you a referral if you want a method they can't provide. Both community-based and facility-based services are safe, effective, and free or low-cost. You can start by seeing your local CHW, and they'll guide you to the right place based on which method you choose.
responses.model_response:
Yes—​in Rwanda, trained Community Health Workers (CHWs), often called “Animatrices,” are allowed to start or refill several contraceptive methods right in the community. You would only need to visit the health centre for methods that a CHW is not certified to provide.

1. Methods a CHW can START and REFILL  
   • Male or female condoms  
     – Effectiveness: Typical use ≈ 85 % effective, perfect use ≈ 98 %.  
   • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) and progestin-only pills (POPs)  
     – Typical use ≈ 93 %, perfect use ≈ 99 +.  
   • Sub-cutaneous 3-monthly depot injection (DMPA-SC, often “Sayana Press”)  
     – Typical use ≈ 96 %, perfect use ≈ 99 +.  
   • Emergency contraceptive pills (ECP) for occasional back-up or after unprotected sex  
     – Reduces risk of pregnancy by 58-95 % depending on how soon taken.  
   • Standard Days Method (CycleBeads) and Lactational Amenorrhoea Method (LAM) counselling and supplies.

   CHWs use the WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC) screening tool. If no Category-3 or 4 condition is found, they can give the method immediately (same-day start). Services from CHWs are free of charge.

2. Methods that REQUIRE a visit to the health centre or hospital  
   • Implants (e.g. Jadelle, Implanon)  
   • Copper-IUD or hormonal IUD  
   • Intramuscular DMPA-IM (if the facility has not trained the CHW)  
   • Permanent methods (female sterilisation / male vasectomy)  
   • Any method when a complicated medical condition is suspected (MEC 3 or 4)

   Your CHW can write a referral note and, if you wish, help arrange transport or accompany you.

3. What to expect from the CHW visit  
   • Private, non-judgemental counselling using the Balanced Counselling Strategy (BCS+) job aids.  
   • Discussion of your preferences, medical history and lifestyle.  
   • Explanation of how each available method works, effectiveness, side-effects, warning signs, and how to switch or stop.  
   • Adolescents and unmarried clients can receive services without parental or partner consent, according to the Rwanda National FP Policy (2021).  

4. General side-effects and when to seek care  
   • Pills: possible mild nausea, breast tenderness or spotting; seek care for severe headaches, chest pain, or vision changes.  
   • DMPA-SC: irregular bleeding, delayed return to fertility; seek care for very heavy bleeding or severe lower-leg pain.  
   • Condoms: no hormonal effects; seek care only if allergic reaction or signs of STI.  

5. Warning signs that need prompt medical review (go to the health centre)  
   • Severe abdominal or chest pain, vision problems, sudden severe headaches, very heavy bleeding, or injection-site infection.  
   • Any side-effect that worries you or interferes with daily life.  

6. Cost and confidentiality  
   • CHW services and most contraceptive supplies are free.  
   • Information you share remains confidential unless you request otherwise.

If you already know which method you want from the list a CHW can provide, you can go directly to her. If you are not sure, she can help you decide or refer you for a wider range of options.

must_include: CHWs can provide birth control pills and condoms
For implant, IUD, or Depo shot, you need to visit health center
CHWs can counsel on all methods and provide referrals
Both options are safe and effective
must_avoid: Saying CHWs can't help with contraception
Not clarifying which methods CHWs can provide

non_compliant_indicators: Doesn't differentiate methods by provider level

responses.scenario: I can't afford to pay for contraception. Are there free options in Rwanda?
responses.ground_truth: Contraception is free or very low-cost at public health facilities in Rwanda. All contraceptive methods - pills, implants, IUDs, Depo injections, condoms - are available at no cost or minimal cost at health centers and district hospitals. If you have Mutuelle de Santé (community health insurance), family planning services are covered. Even without insurance, contraception is provided free or at very low cost because the government prioritizes family planning access. You can visit any public health center, district hospital, or even see a Community Health Worker for some methods. Cost should not be a barrier - you have the right to access the contraceptive method that works best for you.
responses.model_response:
I’m glad you asked—cost should never be a barrier to choosing the method that is right for you. Below is a summary of what is available free-of-charge or at very low cost in Rwanda, together with key facts you may want to consider. The information is consistent with the 2022 WHO Family Planning Handbook, the WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC), the Balanced Counseling Strategy (BCS+), and the Rwanda National Family Planning Policy (2021).

1. Where you can get free or very low-cost contraception in Rwanda
• Public health centres and district hospitals: The Ministry of Health supplies most contraceptive methods at no charge.  
• Community Health Workers (CHWs or “binômes”) in every village provide short-acting methods such as condoms, combined oral contraceptive pills, progestin-only pills, and injectables (Sayana Press or DMPA) free or for a symbolic fee (usually 100–200 RWF to cover supplies).  
• Youth corners and adolescent-friendly services: Adolescents and unmarried people have the same right to obtain contraception without parental or partner consent.  
• Social health insurance (Mutuelle de Santé) covers insertion and removal fees for long-acting reversible methods (implants, IUDs) and permanent methods.  

Tip: Bring your Mutuelle de Santé card or any other insurance card if you have one; however, you will not be turned away if you do not have it.

2. Overview of free/low-cost methods and their effectiveness
(Typical-use effectiveness reflects real-life use; perfect-use effectiveness reflects correct, consistent use every time.)

Short-acting, user-controlled:  
• External (male) condoms – 87 % effective typical use; 98 % perfect use. Also protect against STIs/HIV.  
• Internal (female) condoms – 79 % typical; 95 % perfect.  
• Combined oral contraceptive pills – 93 % typical; >99 % perfect.  
• Progestin-only pills – 93 % typical; >99 % perfect.  
• Emergency contraceptive pills (ECPs) – 58–95 % effective depending on how soon after sex they are taken (best within 72 h). ECPs are free at most public facilities.

Short-acting, provider-administered:  
• Injectable (DMPA 3-month) – 96 % typical; >99 % perfect. Self-injection (Sayana Press) training is available in many sites.

Long-acting reversible contraception (LARC):  
• Implants (e.g., Jadelle®, Implanon NXT®) – >99 % effective for 3–5 years; free insertion/removal under national insurance.  
• Copper IUD – >99 % effective for up to 12 years; no hormones.  
• Hormonal IUD (LNG-IUS) – >99 % effective for up to 5 years (availability varies; usually free in public hospitals).

Permanent methods (require surgery, only if you are sure you do not want future pregnancies):  
• Tubal ligation (female sterilization) – >99 % effective.  
• Vasectomy (male sterilization) – >99 % effective.  
Both are provided free or for a nominal fee at district hospitals and through periodic outreach camps.

3. What about side-effects and warning signs?
Each method has its own profile. When you visit a provider or CHW, you will receive balanced counseling on:
• Common side-effects (e.g., changes in bleeding with implants, IUDs, or injectables; mild nausea or breast tenderness with pills).  
• Rare but serious warning signs (e.g., severe abdominal pain, very heavy bleeding, fever after insertion).  
• When to seek care immediately.

4. Medical eligibility
Most healthy people are medically eligible (WHO MEC category 1) for the pill, injectables, implants, IUDs, or condoms. If you have a specific condition (e.g., high blood pressure, diabetes, HIV, or you are breastfeeding a baby <6 weeks old), the provider will use the WHO MEC wheel to ensure the safest options for you.

5. How to decide
It is your choice. You can start, switch, or stop a method at any time. Think about:
• Effectiveness  
• How often you want to remember something (daily pill vs. 3-month injection vs. 5-year implant)  
• Side-effects you could accept  
• Whether STI protection is important  
• Personal or partner preferences

You do not have to decide alone—the provider’s role is to give you complete, unbiased information, not to pressure you.

6. Next steps
• Visit your nearest health centre, youth corner, or speak to a CHW. Tell them you would like family planning. Services are confidential.  
• If you ever experience unusual symptoms after starting a method, return to the facility or call 114 (Rwanda MOH hotline).  
• Keep your own reproductive goals central; you can revisit your choice anytime.

If anything is unclear, feel free to ask. You deserve a method that fits your life and budget.

responses.scenario: I just had a baby at the health center. When will they talk to me about family planning?
responses.ground_truth: Congratulations on your baby! In Rwanda, family planning is integrated into maternal health services, so health providers will talk to you about family planning soon - often before you leave the health center or during your postnatal visits. Some methods like the IUD or implant can even be provided immediately after delivery (postplacental insertion) if you're interested. During your postnatal care visits, providers will discuss your options based on whether you're breastfeeding and your preferences. You don't have to wait - you can start planning for spacing your children right away. Providers will help you choose a method that's safe while breastfeeding and fits your family goals.
responses.model_response:
Congratulations on the birth of your baby, and thank you for asking about family planning (FP).

When you can expect counselling
1. Before you leave the maternity ward (within the first 24–48 hours).  WHO and the Rwanda FP policy recommend that every woman receive FP counselling before discharge. If no one has come yet, feel free to ask the midwife or nurse—your request is welcome.
2. At your first post-natal visit (within 7 days) and again at the routine 6-week mother-baby check or when the baby receives immunisations.  Health staff will revisit your FP needs at each visit.
3. Any other time you come to the facility (e.g., for child-immunisation, growth monitoring, or if you simply walk in and ask).  Services are free or very low-cost in public facilities.

Why counselling is offered early
• Fertility can return as soon as 4–6 weeks if you are not exclusively breastfeeding, so having a plan before then is important.  
• Exclusive breastfeeding delays fertility for many women, but only meets the criteria for the Lactational Amenorrhoea Method (LAM) for up to 6 months and only when menses have not yet returned.  
• Some highly effective methods (e.g., postpartum IUD, implant) can be provided right after birth, before discharge, while others (e.g., combined pills) are started later depending on breastfeeding.

Your rights and options
• You have the right to ask questions and choose—or decline—any method, regardless of age or marital status.  
• Counselling must be non-judgmental and confidential.  
• If you ever feel rushed or not fully informed, you can request more information or a different provider.

What you can do now
• Let the nurse or midwife know you would like FP counselling before you go home.  
• Think about whether you would like spacing (at least 2 years before the next pregnancy is healthiest for mother and baby) or limiting.  
• Consider whether you want a method that can be started immediately (e.g., postpartum IUD within 48 hours, implant) or one that can be started later (e.g., injectables, pills, condoms, LAM).  
• Bring up any medical conditions or medications you have—this helps the provider use the WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria to find safe methods for you.

If you have any doubts or if no one offers counselling before discharge, simply say: “I’d like to talk about family planning before going home.” The team is there to support you.

responses.scenario: Should I bring my husband with me when I go to get contraception?
responses.ground_truth: You can access contraception with or without your husband - the choice is yours. Rwanda's family planning program encourages partner involvement because discussing family planning together can strengthen couples' decisions. If you'd like to bring your husband, providers can offer couples counseling where you discuss options together. However, you don't need his permission or presence to access contraception. Providers respect your right to make your own decisions about your reproductive health. Some women prefer to discuss with their partners first, while others choose independently - both are completely acceptable. The most important thing is that you get the method that works best for you and your family goals.
responses.model_response:
It is entirely up to you.  
Here are some points to consider so you can decide what feels right for you:

1. Your right to confidential services  
• In Rwanda, every woman—including adolescents and women who are not married—has the legal right to obtain family-planning services without a partner’s or parent’s permission and without extra cost at public facilities.  
• Health-care workers are trained to provide confidential, non-judgmental care whether you come alone or with someone.

2. Possible advantages of bringing your husband (or another support person)  
• Shared understanding: Both of you hear the same information about options, how well they work, side-effects, warning signs, and when to seek help.  
• Support for correct and consistent use: For methods that require partner cooperation (e.g., condoms, fertility awareness) or follow-up visits (e.g., injectable or implant removal), having your husband on board can make use easier.  
• Joint decision-making: Some couples feel more comfortable choosing a method together, which can strengthen communication.  
• Reduced misconceptions: He can ask questions directly and receive accurate information from the provider.

3. Possible disadvantages  
• Privacy: You may feel less free to ask sensitive questions or to choose a method that differs from what he prefers.  
• Time & logistics: Coordinating schedules can delay your visit or require additional transport costs.  
• Potential pressure: If you worry that his presence might influence your decision in a way you are not comfortable with, coming alone first might be better.

4. Approaches some clients use  
• Come alone for the first visit to get information, then return with your husband if you decide you both want more discussion.  
• Invite him only if you think it will enhance support, especially for methods that need partner cooperation.  
• Use written or digital information from the clinic to discuss at home if he cannot or prefers not to attend.

5. The provider’s role  
Whether you come alone or together, the provider should:  
• Offer balanced counseling on all WHO-approved methods, tailored to your health needs and preferences.  
• Respect your final choice (autonomy).  
• Maintain confidentiality.  
• Address any concerns and explain side-effects, warning signs, and follow-up.

6. When partner involvement is especially helpful (but still not required)  
• Barrier methods (male or female condoms) – correct use involves both partners.  
• Fertility awareness methods – daily cooperation is needed.  
• If you anticipate difficulty attending follow-up visits (e.g., injectables every 3 months, implant removal) and want logistical support.  
• If you desire dual protection (preventing both pregnancy and HIV/STIs) and need agreement on condom use.

In summary: You do not have to bring your husband, but you may choose to if you think it will help with communication, support, or method use. Decide what feels safest and most comfortable for you. If you remain unsure, you can always visit a clinic alone first, talk with the provider, and then decide whether to involve him later.
